play.title:
M. VVilliam Shake-ſpeare
HIS
Hiſtory, of King Lear.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I Thought the King had more affeƈted the Duke of Albeny then Cornewall.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: It did alwaies ſeeme ſo to vs, but now in the diuiﬁon of the Kingdomes, it appeares not which of the Dukes he values moﬅ, for equalities are ſo weighed, that curioﬁty in neither, can make choiſe of eithers moytie.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is not this your ſonne, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: His breeding ﬁr hath beene at my charge. I haue ſo often bluſht to acknowledge him, that now I am braz’d to it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot conceiue you.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Sir, this young fellowes mother could, whereupon ſhe grew round wombed, and had indeed Sir a ſonne for her Cradle, ere ſ had a husband for her bed, do you ſmell a fault?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot wiſh the fault vndone, the iﬀue of it being ſo proper.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: But I haue ﬁr a ſonne by order of Law, ſome yeare elder then this, who yet is no deerer in my account, thogh this knaue came ſomething ſawcely into the world before he was ſent for, yet was his mother faire, there was good ſport at his making, & the whoreſon muﬅ be acknowledged, do you know this noble gentleman,Edmund?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: My Lord of Kent, remember him heereafter as my honourable friend.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: My ſeruices to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I muﬅ loue you, and ſue to know you better.

speech.speaker: Baﬆ.
speech.line: Sir, I ſhall ﬅudy deſeruing.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: He hath beene out nine yeares, and away he ſhall again, the King is comming.

sceneref.stagedir: Sound a Sennet, Enter one bearing a Coronet, then Lear, then the Dukes of Albany and Cornwall, next Gonorill, Regan, Cordelia, with followers.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Attend my Lords of France and Burgundy, Gloﬅer.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I ſhall my Leige.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Meane time we will expreﬀe our darker purpoſes,
The Map there; know we haue diuided
In three our Kingdome; and tis out firﬅ intent,
To ſhake all cares and buﬁineﬀe of our ﬅate,
Confirming them on younger yeares,
The two great Princes, France and Burgundy,
Great Riuals in our youngeﬅ daughters loue,
Long in our Court haue made their amorous ſoiourne,
And here are to be anſwer’d; tell me my daughters,
Which of you ſhall we ſay doth loue vs moﬅ,
That we our largeﬅ bounty may extend,
Where merit doth moﬅ challenge it:
Gonorill our eldeﬅ borne, ſpeake firﬅ.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Sir, I do loue you more then words can wield the matter,
Dearer then eye-ﬁght, ſpace, or liberty,
Beyond what can be valued rich or rare,
No leﬀe then life; with grace, health, beauty, honour,
As much a childe ere loued, or father friend,
A loue that makes breath poore, and ſpeech vnable,
Beyond all manner of ſo much I loue you.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What ſhall Cordelia do, loue and be ﬁlent.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Of all theſe bounds, euen from this line to this,
With ſhady Forreﬅs, and wide skirted Meads,
We make thee Lady, to thine and Albanies iﬀue,
Be this perpetuall. What ſaies our ſecond daughter?
Our deereﬅ Regan, wife to Cornwall, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sir I am made of the ſelfe-ſame mettall that my ﬁﬅer is
And prize me at her worth in my true heart,
I finde ſhe names my very deed of loue, onely ſhee came ſhort,
That I profeﬀe my ſelfe an enemy to all other ioyes,
Which the moﬅ precious ſquare of ſence poﬀeﬀes,
And finde I am alone felicitate in your deere highneﬀe loue.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Then poore Cordelia, and yet not ſo, ﬁnce I am ſure
My loue’s more richer then my tongue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To thee and thine hereditary euer
Remaine this ample third of our faire kingdome,
No leﬁe in ſpace, validity, and pleaſure,
Then that confirm’d on Gonorill; but now our ioy,
Although the laﬅ, not leaﬅ in our deere loue,
What can you ſay to win a third, more opulent
Then your ﬁﬅters.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How, nothing can come of nothing, ſpeake againe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Vnhappy that I am, I cannot heaue my heart into my mouth, I loue your Maieﬅy according to my bond, nor more not leﬀe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Go too, go too, mend your ſpeech a little,
Leaﬅ it may marre your fortunes.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Good my Lord,
You haue begot me, bred me, loued me,
I returne thoſe duties backe as are right fit,
Obey you, loue you, and moﬅ honour you,
Why haue my ﬁﬅers husbands, if they ſay they loue you all,
Haply when I ſhall wed, that Lord whoſe hand
Muﬅ take my plight, ſhall carry halfe my loue with him,
Halfe my care and duty, ſure I ſhall neuer
Marry like my ﬁﬅers, to loue my father all.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: But goes this with thy heart?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So young and ſo vntender?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: So young my Lord, and true.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Well let it be ſo, thy truth be thy dower,
For by the ſacred radience of the Sunne,
The miﬅtreﬀe of Heccat, and the might,
By all the operation of the Orbes,
From whom we do exﬁﬅ and ceaſe to be,
Heere I diſclaime all my paternall care,
Propinquity and property of bloud,
And as a ﬅranger to my heart and me,
Hold thee from this for euer, the barbarous Scythian,
Or he that makes his generation
Meﬀes to gorge his appetite,
Shall be as well neighbour’d, pittied and releeued,
As thou my ſome-time daughter.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Liege.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Peace Kent,come not betweene the Dragon and his wrath
I lou’d her moﬅ, and thought to ſet my reﬅ
On her kinde nurſery, hence and auoid my ﬁght:
So be my graue my peace as heere I giue,
Her fathers heart from her; call France, who ﬅirres?
Call Burgundy, Cornwall, and Albany,
With my two daughters dower digeﬅ this third,
Let pride, which ſhe cals plainneﬀe, marry her:
I do inueﬅ you ioyntly in my power,
Preheminence, and all the large effeƈts
That troope with Maieﬅy, our ſelfe by monthly courſe
With reſeruation of an hundred Knights,
By you to be ſuﬅain’d, ſhall our abode
Make with you by due turnes, onely we ﬅill retaine
The name and all the additions to a King,
The ſway, reuenue, execution of the reﬅ,
Beloued ſonnes be yours, which to confirme,
This Coronet part betwixt you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Royall Lear,
Whom I haue euer honor’d as my King,
Loued as my Father, as my Maﬅer followed,
As my great Patron thought on in my praiers.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The bow is bent and drawne, make from the ſhaft.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Let it fall rather,
Though the forke inuade the region of my heart,
Be Kent vnmannerly, when Lear is mad,
What wilt thou do old man, think’ﬅ thou that duty
Shall haue dread to ſpeake, when power to flattery bowes,
To plainneﬀe honours bound, when Maieﬅy ﬅoops to folly,
Reuerſe thy doome, and in thy beﬅ conﬁderation
Checke this hideous raſhneﬀe, anſwer my life,
My iudgement, thy yongeﬅ daughter does not loue thee leaﬅ,
Nor are thoſe empty hearted, whoſe low ſound
Reuerbs no hollowneﬀe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Kent, on thy life no more.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My life I neuer held but as a pawne
To wage againﬅ thy enemies, nor feare to loſe it
Thy ſafety being the motiue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Out of my ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: See better Lear, and let me ﬅill remaine
The true blanke of thine eie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now by Apollo―

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now by Apollo, King thou ſwear’ﬅ thy Gods in vaine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vaﬀall,recreant.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Do, kill thy Phyﬁtion,
And the fee beﬅow vpon the foule diſeaſe,
Reuoke thy doome, or whilﬅ I can vent clamour
From my throat, ile tell thee thou doﬅ euill.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Heare me, on thy alleigeance heare me;
Since thou haﬅ ſought to make vs breake our vow,
Which we durﬅ neuer yet; and with ﬅraied pride,
To come betweene our ſentence and our power,
Which, nor our nature, nor our place can beare,
Our potency make good, take thy reward,
Foure dayes we do allot thee for prouiﬁon,
To ſhield thee from diſeaſes of the world,
And on the fift to turne thy hated backe
Vpon our kingdome; if on the tenth day following,
Thy baniſht trunke be found in our Dominions,
The moment is thy death, away,
By Iupiter, this ſhall not be reuokt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why fare thee well King, ﬁnce thou wilt appeare,
Friendſhip liues hence, and baniſhment is here;
The Gods to their proteƈtion take the maid,
That rightly thinkes, and hath moﬅ iuﬅly ſaid,
And your large ſpeeches may your deeds approue,
That good effeƈts may ſpring from words of loue:
Thus Kent, O Princes, bids you all adew,
Hee’l ſhape his old courſe in a Country new.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter France and Burgundy with Gloceﬆer.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Heer’s France and Burgundy, my noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My Lord or Burgundy, we firﬅ addreﬀ towards you,
Who with a King hath riuald for our daughter,
What in the leaﬅ will you require in preſent
Dower with her, or ceaſe your queﬅ of loue?

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Roiall Maieﬅy,I craue no more then what
Your Highneﬀ offered, nor will you tender leﬀe?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Right noble Burgundy, when ſhe was deare to vs,
We did hold her ſo, but now her price is fallen;
Sir, there ſhe ﬅands, if ought within that little
Seeming ſubﬅance, or all of it with our diſpleaſure peec’ﬅ,
And nothin elſe may fitly like your Grace,
Shee’s there, and ſhe is yours.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: I know no anſwer.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Sir, will you with thoſe infirmities ſhe owes,
Vnfriended, new adopted to our hate,
Couered with our curſe, and ﬅranger’d with our oath,
Take her or leaue her.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Pardon me royall ﬁr, eleƈtion makes not vp
On ſuch conditions.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then leaue her ﬁr, for by the power that made me,
I tell you all her wealth. For you great King,
I would not from your loue make ſuch a ﬅray,
To match you where I hate, therefore beſeech you,
To auert your liking a more worthier way,
Then on a wretch whom Nature is aſham’d
Almoﬅ to acknowledge hers.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: This is moﬅ ﬅrange, that ſhe that euen but now
Was you beﬅ obieƈt, the argument of your praiſe,
Balme of your age, moﬅ beﬅ, moﬅ deereﬅ,
Should in this trice of time commit a thing
So monﬅrous, to diſmantle ſo many foulds of fauour,
Sure her offence muﬅ be of ſuch vnnaturall degree,
That monﬅers it, or you for voucht affeƈtions
Falne into taint, which to beleeue of her
Muﬅ be a faith that reaſon without miracle
Could neuer plaint in me.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: I yet beſeech your Maieﬅy,
If for I want that glib and oily Art,
To ſpeake and purpoſe not, ﬁnce what I well intend,
Ile do’t before I ſpeake, that you may know
It is no vicious blot, murder, or fouleneﬀe,
No vncleane aƈtion or diſhonoured ﬅep
That hath depriu’d me of your grace and fauour,
But euen for want of that, for which I am rich,
A ﬅill ſoliciting eye, and ſuch a tongue,
As I am glad I haue not, though not to haue it,
Hath loﬅ me in your liking.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Go to, goe to, better thou hadﬅ not bene borne,
Then not to haue pleas’d me better.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Is it no more but this, a tardineﬀe in nature,
That often leaues the hiﬅory vnſpoke that it intends to do,
My Lord of Burgundy, what ſay you to the Lady?
Loue is not loue when it is mingled with reſpeƈts that ﬅands
Aloofe from the entire point, will you haue her?
She is her ſelfe and dower.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Royall Lear, giue but that portion
Which your ſelfe propos’d, and here I take
Cordelia by the hand, Dutcheﬀe of Burgundy.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nothing, I haue ſworne.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: I am ſorry then you haue ſo loﬅ a father,
That you muﬅ loſe a husband.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Peace be with Burgundy, ﬁnce that reſpeƈts
Of fortune are his loue, I ſhall not be his wife.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Faireﬅ Cordelia, that art moﬅ rich being poore,
Moﬅ choiſe forſaken, and moﬅ loued deſpis’d,
Thee and thy vertues heere I ſeize vpon,
Be it lawfull I take vp what’s caﬅ away.
Gods, Gods! tis ﬅrange, that from their cold’ﬅ negleƈt,
My loue ſhould kindle to enflam’d reſpeƈt,
Thy dowreleﬀe daughter King, throwne to thy chance,
Is Queene of vs, of ours, and our faire France:
Not all the Dukes in watriſh Burgundy,
Shall buy this vnpriz’d precious maid of me.
Bid them farwell Cordelia, though vnkinde
Thou loſeﬅ heere, a better where to finde.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou haﬅ her France, let her be thine,
For we haue no ſuch daughter, nor ſhall euer ſee
That face of hers againe, therefore be gone,
Without our grace, our loue, our benizon: come noble Burgundy.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Bid farwell to your ﬁﬅers.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: The Iewels of our Father,
With waſht eyes Cordelia leaues you, I know you what you are,
And like a ﬁﬅer am moﬅ loth to call your faults
As they are named, vſe well our Father,
To your profeﬀed boſomes I commit him,
But yet alaﬀe, ﬅood I within his grace,
I would preferre him to a better place;
So farwell to you both.

speech.speaker: Gonorill.
speech.line: Preſcribe not vs our duties.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Let your ﬅudy be to content your Lord,
Who hath receiu’d you at Fortunes almes,
You haue obedience ſcanted,
And well are worth the worth that you haue wanted.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Time ſhall vnfold what pleated cunning hides,
Who couers faults, at laﬅ ſhame derides:
Well may you proſper.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: Come faire Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Siﬅer, it is not a little I haue to ſay,
Of what moﬅ neerely appertaines to vs both,
I thinke our father will hence to night.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: That’s moﬅ certaine, and with you, next month with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ſee how full of changes his age is, the obſeruation we haue made of it hath not beene little; he alwaies loued our ﬁﬅer moﬅ, and with what poore iudgement hee hath now caﬅ her off, appeares too groﬀe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Tis the infirmity of his age, yet he hath euer but ﬂenderly knowne himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gono.
speech.line: The beﬅ and ſoundeﬅ of his time hath bin but raſh, then muﬅ we looke to receiue frō his age, not alone the imperfeƈtion of long ingrafted condition, but therwithal vnruly waiwardnes, that infirme and cholericke yeares bring with them.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Such vnconﬅant ﬅars are we like to haue from him, as this of Kents baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Gono.
speech.line: There is further complement of leaue taking between France and him, pray lets hit together, if our Father cary authority with ſuch diſpoﬁtions as he beares, this laﬅ ſurrender of his will but offend vs.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: We ſhall further thinke on’t.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: We muﬅ do ſomething,and it’h heate.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Thou Nature art my Goddeﬀe, to thy law my ſeruices are bound, wherefore ſhould I ﬅand in the plague of cuﬅome, and permit the curioﬀty of Nations to depriue me, for that I am ſome 12. or 14. moone-ſhines lag of a brother: why baﬅard? wherefore baſe, when my dementions are as well compaƈt, my minde as generous, & my ſhape as true as honeﬅ madams iﬀue, why brand they vs with baſe, baſe baﬅtardy? who in the luﬅy ﬅealth of nature, take more compoﬁtion and fierce quality, then doth within a ﬅate dull lied bed, goe to the creating of a whole tribe of fops got tweene ﬂeepe and wake; well the legitimate Edgar, I muﬅ haue your land, our Fathers loue is to the baﬅard Edmund, as to the legitimate: well my legitimate, if this letter ſpeed, and my inuention thriue, Edmundthe baſe ſhall tooth’legitimate: I grow, I proſper, now Gods ﬅand vp for Baﬅards.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Kent baniſht thus, and France in choller parted, and the King gone to night, ſubſcrib’d his power, confined to exhibition, all this done vpon the gad; Edmund, how now, what newes?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Lordſhip, none.

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: Why ſo earneﬅly ſeeke you to put vp that letter?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I know no newes, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: What paper were you reading?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord,

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: No, what needs then that terrible diſpatch of it into your pocket, the quality of nothing hath not ſuch need to hide it ſelfe, lets ſee, come if it be nothing I ſhal not need ſpeƈtacles.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I beſeech you ﬁr pardon me, it is a Letter from my brother, that I haue not all ore read, for ſo much as I haue peruſed, I finde it not fit for your liking.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Giue me the letter ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I ſhall offend, either to detaine or giue it, the contents as in part I vnderﬅand them, are too blame.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Lets ſee, Lets ſee.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I hope for my brothers iuﬅification, he wrote this but as an eﬀay, or taﬅe of my vertue.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: This policy of age makes the world bitter to the beﬅ of our times, keepes our fortunes from vs till our oldneﬀe cannot relliſh them, I begin to finde an idle and fond bondage in the oppreﬃon of aged tyranny, who ſwaies not as it hath power, but as it is ſuffered, come to mee, that of this I may ſpeake more; if our Father would ﬂeepe till I wakt him, you ſhould enioy halfe his reuenew for euer, and liue the beloued of your brother Edgar.
Hum, conſpiracy, ﬂept till I wakt him, you ſhould enioy halfe his reuenew: my ſonne Edgar, had he a hand to write this, a hart and braine to breed it in? when came this to you, who brought it?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: It was not brought me my Lord, there’s the cunuing of it, I found it throwne in at the caſement of my Cloſet.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: You know the carraƈter to be your brothers?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: If the matter were good, my Lord, I durﬅ ſweare it were his, but in reſpeƈt of that, I would faine thinke it were not,

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Is it his?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: It is his hand my Lord, but I hope his heart is not in the contents.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Hath he neuer heeretofore ſounded you in this buﬁneﬀe?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Neuer my Lord, but I haue often heard him maintaine it to be fit, that ſonnes at perfit age, and fathers declining, his father ſhould be as Ward to the ſonne, and the ſonne mannage the reuenew.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: O villaine, villaine, his very opinion in the Letter, abhorrid villaine, vnnaturall, deteﬅed bruitiſh villaine, worſe then bruitiſh go ﬁr ſeeke him; I, apprehend him, abhominable villaine, where is he?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I do not well know my Lord, if it ſhall pleaſe you to ſuſpend your indignation againﬅ my brother, till you can deriue from him better teﬅimony of this intent, you ſhal runnne a certaine courſe, where if you violently proceed againﬅ him, miﬅaking his purpoſe, it would make a great gap in your owne honour, and ſhake in peeces the heart of his obedience, I dare pawne downe my life for him, hee hath wrote this to feele my affeƈtion to your Honour, and to no further pretence of danger.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Thinke you ſo?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: If your Honour iudge it meete, I will place you where you ſhall heare vs conferre of this, and by an aurigular aﬀurance haue your ſatisfaƈtion, and that without any further delay then this very euening.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: He cannot be ſuch a monﬅer.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Nor is not ſure.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: To his father, that ſo tenderly and entirely loues him: heauen and earth! Edmund ſeeke him out, winde me into him, I pray you frame your buﬁnes after your own wiſedome, I wold vnﬅate my ſelfe to be in a due reſolution.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I ſhall ſeeke him ﬁr preſently, conuey the buﬁneﬀe as I ſhall ſee meanes, and acquaint you withall.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Theſe late Eclipſes in the Sunne and Moone, portend no good to vs, though the wiſedome of nature can reaſon thus and thus, yet nature findes it ſelfe ſcourg’d by the ſequent effeƈts, loue cooles, friendſhip fals off, brothers diuide, in Cities mutinies, in Countries diſcords, Pallaces treaſon, the bond crackt betweene ſonne and father; finde out this villaine, Edmund it ſhall loſe thee nothing, do it carefully; and the noble and true hearted Kent baniſht, his offence honeﬅ; ﬅtrange, ﬅrange!

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that when we are ﬁcke in Fortune, often the ſurfet of our owne behauiour, we make guilty of our diſaﬅers, the Sunne, the Moone, and the ﬅars, as if we were villaines by neceﬃty, fooles by heauenly compulﬁon, knaues, theeues, and trecherers by ſpirituall predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforc’ﬅ obedience of planitary influence, and all that we are euill in, by a diuine thruﬅing on, an admirable euaﬁon of whore-maﬅer man, to lay his goatiſh diſpoﬁion to the charge of ﬅars: my Father compounded with my Mother vnder the Dragons taile, & my natiuity was vnder Vrſa maior, ſo that it followes I am rough & lecherous; Fut, I ſhould haue beene that I am, had the maidenleﬅ ﬅarre of the Firmament twinckled on my baﬅardy; Edgar,
& out he comes like the Cataﬅrophe of the old Comedy, mine is villanous melancholy, with a ﬁgh like them of Bedlam; O theſe Ecclipſes do portend theſe diuiﬁons.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: How now brother Edmund, what ſerious contemplation are you in?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I am thinking brother of a prediƈtion I read this other day, what ſhould follow theſe Ecclipſes.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Doe you buﬁe your ſelfe about that?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I promiſe you the effeƈts he writ of, ſucceed vnhappily, as of vnnaturalneﬀe betweene the childe and the parent, death, dearth, diﬀolutions of ancient armies, diuiﬁons in ﬅate, menaces and malediƈtions againﬅ King and Nobles, needleﬀe diffidences, baniſhment of friends, diﬃpation of Cohorts, nuptiall breaches, and I know not what.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How long haue you bin a ſeƈtary Aﬅronomicall?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Come, come, when ſaw you my father laﬅ?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why the night gone by.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Spake you with him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Two houres together.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Parted you in good tearmes? found you no diſpleaſure in him by word or countenance?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: None at all.

speech.speaker: ﬅ.
speech.line: Bethinke your ſelfe wherein you may haue offended him, and at my entreaty, forbeare his preſence, till ſome little time hath qualified the heate of his diſpleaſure, which at this inﬅant ſo rageth in him, that with the miſchiefe of your perſon it would ſcarſe allay.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Some villaine hath done me wrong.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: That’s my feare brother, I aduiſe you to the beﬅ, goe arm’d, I am no honeﬅ man if there be any good meaning towards you, I haue told you what I haue ſeen & heard, but faintly, nothing like the image and horror of it; pray you away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Shall I heare from you anon?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I do ſerue you in this buﬁneﬀe:
A credulous Father, and a brother noble,
Whoſe nature is ſo farre from doing harmes,
That he ſuſpeƈts none, on whoſe fooliſh honeﬅy
My praƈtiſes ride eaﬁe, I ſee the buﬁneﬀe,
Let me if not by birth, haue lands by wit,
All with me’s meete, that I can faſhion fit.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Did my Farher ﬅrike my gentleman for chiding of his foole?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Yes Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: By day and night he wrongs me,
Euery houre he flaſes into one groﬀe crime or other,
That ſets vs all at ods, Ile not endure it;
His knights grow riotous and himſelfe vpbraids vs
On euery trifle when he returnes from hunting,
I will not ſpeake with him, ſay I am ﬁcke,
If you come ﬂacke of former ſeruices,
You ſhall do well, the fault of it Ile anſwer.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Hee’s comming Madam, I heare him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Put on what weary negligence you pleaſe, you and your fellow-ſeruants, Ide haue it come in queﬅion, if he diﬂike it, let him to our ﬁﬅer, whoſe minde & mine I know in that are one, not to be ouer-rulde; idle olde man that ﬅill would manage thoſe authorities that he hath giuen away, now by my life olde fooles are babes againe, and muﬅ be vſed with checkes as flatteries, when they are ſeene abus’d, remember what I tell you.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Very well, Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: And let his Knights haue colder lookes among you, what growes of it no matter, aduiſe your fellowes ſo, I would breed from hence occaﬁons, and I ſhall, that I may ſpeake, Ile write ﬅraight to my ﬁﬅer to hold my very courſe; goe prepare for dinner.

speech.speaker: Ken.
speech.line: If but as well I other accents borrow, that can my ſpeech defuſe, my good intent may carry through it ſelfe to that ful iﬀue for which I raizd my likeneﬀe; now baniﬅt Kent, if thou canﬅ ſerue where thou doﬅ ﬅand condemn’d, thy maﬅer whom thou loueﬅ, ſhall finde the full of labour.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me not ﬅay a iot for dinner, goe get it ready: how now, what art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A man ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What doﬅ thou profeﬁe? what wouldﬅ thou with vs?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I doe profeﬀe to bee no leﬀe then I ſeeme, to ſerue him truely that wil put me in truﬅ, to loue him that is honeﬅ, to conuerſe with him that is wiſe and ſaies little, to feare iudgement, to fight when I cannot chuſe, and to eate no fiſh.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A very honeﬅ hearted fellow, and as poore as the King.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou be as poore for a ſubieƈt, as he is for a king, thou art poore enough, what wouldﬅ thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Seruice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who wouldﬅ thou ſerue?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: You.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doﬅ thou know me fellow?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No ﬁr, but you haue that in your countenance, which I would faine call Maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Authority.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſeruices canﬅ thou do?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I can keepe honeﬅ counſaile, ride, run, marre a curious tale in telling it, and deliuer a plaine meﬀage bluntly, that which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in, and the beﬅ of me, is diligence.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How old art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Not ſo young to loue a woman for ﬁnging, nor ſo old to dote on her for any thing, I haue yeares on my backe forty eight.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Follow me, thou ſhalt ſerue me, if I like thee no worſe after dinner, I will not part from thee yet; dinner ho, dinner, where’s my knaue, my foole, goe you and call my foole hether, you ﬁrra, where’s my daughter?

speech.speaker: Steward.
speech.line: So pleaſe you―

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſaies the fellow there? call the clat-pole backe, where’s my foole? ho, I thinke the world’s aﬂeepe, how now, where’s that mungrell?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: He ſaies my Lord, your daughter is not well.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why came not the ﬂaue backe to me when I call’d him?

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Sir, he anſwered me in the roundeﬅ mannner, hee would not.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: He would not?

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: My Lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my iudgement, your Highneﬀe is not entertain’d with that ceremonious affeƈtion as you were wont, there’s a great abatement appeares as well in the generall dependants, as in the Duke himſelfe alſo, and your daughter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha, ſaiﬅ thou ſo?

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: I beſeech you pardon me my Lord,if I be miﬅaken, for my duty cannot be ﬁlent, when I thinke your Highneﬀe is wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou but remembreﬅ me of mine owne conception, I haue perceiued a moﬅ faint negleƈt of late, which I haue rather blamed as mine owne iealous curioﬁty, then as a very pretence and purport of vnkindnes; I will look further into it, but wher’s this foole? I haue not ſeene him this two daies.

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Since my young Ladies going into France ﬁr, the foole hath much pined away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No more of that, I haue noted it, goe you and tell my daughter, I would ſpeake with her, go you call hither my foole; O you ﬁr, you ﬁr, come you hither, who am I ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My Ladies Father.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My Ladies father, my Lords knaue, you whoreſon dog, you ﬂaue, you curre.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I am none of this my Lord, I beſeech you pardon me.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do you bandy lookes with me you raſcall?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Ile not be ﬅrucke my Lord,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor tript neither, you baſe football plaier.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I thanke thee fellow, thou ſeru’ﬅ me, and ile loue thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Come ﬁr, ile teach you differences, away, away, if you will meaſure your lubbers length againe, tarry, but away, you haue wiſedome.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now friendly knaue I thanke thee, there’s earneﬅ of thy ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Let me hire him too, here’s my coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now my prety knaue, how doﬅ thou?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirra, you were beﬅ take my coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why for taking ones part that’s out of fauour, nay and thou canﬅ not ſmile as the winde ﬁts, thou’t catch colde ſhortly, there take my coxcombe; why this fellow hath baniſt two of his daughters, and done the third a bleﬃng againﬅ his will, if thou follow him, thou muﬅ needs weare my coxcombe, how now nunckle, would I had two coxcombes, and two daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why my boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If I gaue them any liuing, ide keepe my coxcombe my ſelfe, theres mine, beg another of thy daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Take heed ﬁrra, the whip.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Truth is, a dog that muﬅ to kennell, he muﬅ bee whipt out, when Lady oth’e brach may ﬅand by the fire and ﬅinke.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A peﬅilent gull to me.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirra, ile teach thee a ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marke it Vnckle; haue more then thou ſheweﬅ, ſpeake leﬀe then thou knoweﬅ, lend leﬀe then thou oweﬅ, ride more then thou goeﬅ, learne more then thou troweﬅ, ſet leﬀe then thou throweﬅ, leaue thy drinke and thy whore, and keepe in a doore, and thou ſhalt haue more, then two tens to a ſcore.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This is nothing foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then like the breath of an vnfeed Lawyer, you gaue me nothing for it; can you make no vſe of nothing Vncle?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why no boy, nothing can be made out of nothing.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Preethee tell him, ſo much the rent of his land comes to, he will not beleeue a foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A bitter foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Doﬅ thou know the difference my boy, betweene a bitter foole, and a ſweete foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No lad, teach me.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: That Lord that counſaild thee to giue away thy Land,
Come place him heere by me, do thou for him ﬅand,
The ſweete and bitter foole will preſently appeare,
The one in motley here, the other found out there.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doﬅ thou call me foole boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Al thy other Titles thou haﬅ giuen away, that thou waﬅ borne with.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This is not altogether foole my Lord.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: No faith, Lords and great men will not let me, if I had a monopolie out, they would haue part on’t, and lodes too, they will not let me haue all foole to my ſelfe, thei’l be ſnatching; giue me an egge Nunckle, and ile giue thee two crownes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What two crownes ſhall they be?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why after I haue cut the egge in the middle and eate vp the meate, the two crownes of the egge: when thou cloueﬅ thy crowne in the middle, and gaueﬅ away both parts, thou boreﬅ thy aﬀe on thy back ore the dirt, thou hadﬅ little wit in thy bald crowne, when thou gaueﬅ thy golden one away; if I ſpeak like my ſelfe in this, let him be whipt that firﬅ findes it so.
Fooles had nere leﬀe wit in a yeare,
For wiſe men are growne foppiſh,
They know not how their wits do weare,
Their manners are ſo apiſh.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: When were you wont to be ſo full of ſongs ﬁrra?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I haue vſed it Nuncle, euer ﬁnce thou mad’ﬅ thy daughters thy mother, for when thou gaueﬅ them the rod, and putﬅ downe thine owne breeches, then they for ſudden ioy did weep, and I for ſorrow ſung, that ſuch a King ſhould play bo-peepe, and goe the fooles among: prethee Nunckle keepe a ſchoole-maﬅer that can teach thy foole to lie, I would faine learne to lie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If you lie, wee’l haue you whipt.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I maruell what kin thou and thy daughters are, they’l haue me whipt for ſpeaking true, thou wilt haue mee whipt for lying, and ſometime I am whipt for holding my peace, I had rather be any kinde of thing then a foole, and yet I would not bee thee Nunckle, thou haﬅ pared thy wit a both ﬁdes, and left nothing in the middle; heere comes one of the parings.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now daughter, what makes that Frontlet on,
Me-thinkes you are too much alate it’h frowne.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou waﬅ a pretty fellow when thou hadﬅ no neede to care for her frowne, thou, thou art an O without a figure, I am better then thou art now, I am a foole, thou art nothing, yes forſooth I will hold my tongue, ſo your face bids me, though you ſay nothing.
Mum, mum, he that keepes neither cruﬅ nor crum,
Weary of all, ſhall want ſome. That’s a ſheald peſcod.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not onely ﬁr this, your all-licenc’d foole, but other of your inſolent retinue do hourely carpe and quarrell, breaking foorth in ranke and (not to be endured riots) Sir, I had thought by making this well knowne vnto you, to haue found a ſafe redreﬀe, but now grow fearefull by what your ſelfe too late haue ſpoke and done, that you proteƈt this courſe, and put on by your allowance, which if you ſhould, the fault would not ſcape cenſure, nor the redreﬀe ﬂeepe, which in the tender of a wholeſome weal might in their working do you that offence, that elſe were ſhame that then neceﬃty muﬅ call diſcreete proceedings.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: For you trow Nuncle, the hedge-ſparrow fed the Cookow ſo long, that it had it head bit off beit young, ſo out went the Candle, and we were left darkling.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Are you our Daughter?

speech.speaker: Gonorill.
speech.line: Come ﬁr, I would you would make vſe of that good wiſedome whereof I know you are fraught, and put away theſe diſpoﬁtions, that of late transforme you from what you rightly are.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: May not an Aﬀe know when the Cart drawes the horſe, whoop Iug I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Doth any here know me? why this is not Lear; doth Lear walke thus? ſpeake thus? where are his eies, either his notion, weakneﬀe ,or his diſcernings are lethergy, ﬂeeping or waking; ha! ſure tis not ſo, who is it that can tell me who I am? Lears ſhadow? I would learne that, for by the markes of ſoueraignty, knowledge, & reaſon, I ſhould be falſe perſwaded I had daughters.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Which they, will make an obedient Father.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: Your name faire gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Come ﬁr, this admiration is much of the fauour of other your new prankes; I do beſeech you vnderﬅand my purpoſes aright, as you are old and reuerend, you ſhould be wiſe, heere doe you keepe one hundred Knights and Squires, men ſo diſordered, ſo deboyﬅ and bold, that this our Court infeƈted with their manners, ſhewes like a riotous Inne, epicuriſme and luﬅ make more like a Tauerne or Brothell, then a great Pallace, the ſhame it ſelfe doth ſpeake for inﬅant remedy, bee thou deﬁred by her, that elſe will take the thing ſhe begs, a little to diſquantity your traine, and the remainder that ſhall ﬅill depend, to be ſuch men as may beſort your age, and know themſelues and you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Darkneﬀe and Diuels! ſaddle my horſes, call my traine together, degenerate baﬅard, ile not trouble thee; yet haue I left a daughter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ﬅrike my people, and your diſordered rabble, make ſeruants of their betters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: We that too late repent’s vs; O ﬁr, are you come? Is it your will that we prepare any horſes, ingratitude! thou marble-hearted fiend, more hideous when thou ſheweﬅ thee in a childe, then the Sea-monﬅer, deteﬅed kite, thou leﬀen my traine and men of choiſe and rareﬅ parts, that all particulars of duty know, and in the moﬅ exaƈt regard, ſupport the worſhippes of their name, O moﬅ ſmall fault, how vgly didﬅ thou in Cordelia ſhew, that like an engine wrencht my frame of nature from the fixt place, drew from my heart all loue, & added to the gall; ô Lear, Lear! beate at this gate that let thy folly in, and thy deare iudgement out, goe, goe, my people?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: My Lord, I am guiltleﬀe as I am ignorant.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: It may be ſo my Lord, harke Nature heare deere Goddeﬀe, ſuſpend thy purpoſe, if thou didﬅ intend to make this creature fruitefull, into her wombe conuey ﬅerility, dry vp in her the Organs of encreaſe, and from her derogate body neuer ſpring a babe to honor her; if ſhe muﬅ teem, create her childe of ſpleen, that it may liue and be a thourt diſuetur’d torment to her, let it ﬅampe wrinckles in her brow of youth, with accent teares, fret channels in her cheekes, turne all her mothers paines and benefits to laughter and contempt, that ſee may feele, how ſharper then a ſerpents tooth it is, to haue a thankleﬀe childe, goe, goe, my people?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Now Gods that we adore, whereof comes this!

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Neuer affliƈt your ſelfe to know the cauſe, but let his diſpoﬁtion haue that ſcope that dotage giues it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What, fifty of my followers at a clap, within a fortnight?

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: What is the matter ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile tell thee, life and death! I am aſham’d that thou haﬅ power to ſhake my man-hood thus, that theſe hot teares that breake from me perforce, ſhould make the worﬅ blaﬅs and fogs vpon the vntender woundings of a fathers curſe, peruſe euery ſence about the olde fond eies,​be-weepe this cauſe againe, ile plucke you out, and you caﬅ with the waters that you make to temper clay, yea,​is it come to this? yet haue I left a daughter, whom I am ſure is kinde and comfortable, when ſhe ſhall heare this of thee, with her nailes ſhee’l fley thy woluiſh viſage, thou ſhalt finde that ile reſume the ſhape, which thou doeﬅ thinke I haue caﬅ off for euer,​thou ſhalt I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Do you marke that my Lord?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I cannot be ſo partiall Gonorill to the great loue I beare you.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Come ﬁr no more; you, more knaue then foole, after your maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nuncle Lear, Nuncle Lear,tarry and take the foole with a fox when one has caught her, and ſuch a daughter, ſhould ſure to the ﬂaughter, if my cap would buy a halter, ſo the foole followes after.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: What Oſwald, ho.

speech.speaker: Oſwald.
speech.line: Heere Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: What, haue you writ this letter to my ﬁﬅer?

speech.speaker: Oſw.
speech.line: Yes Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Take you ſome company, and away to horſe, informe her full of my particular feares, and thereto adde ſuch reaſons of your owne, as may compaƈt it more, get you gone, and after your returne―now my Lord, this mildie gentleneﬀe and courſe of yours though I diﬂike not, yet vnder pardon y’are much more alapt want of wiſedome, then praiſe for harmfull mildneﬀe.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: How farre your eies may pierce I cannot tell,
Striuing to better ought, we marre what’s well.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Nay then―

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Well, well, the euent.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Go you before to Gloceﬅer with theſe Letters, acquaint my daughter no further with any thing you know, then comes from her demand out of the Letter, if your diligence be not ſpeedie, I ſhall be there before you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I will not ﬂeepe my Lord, till I haue deliuered your letter.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If a mans braines were in his heeles, wert not in danger of kybes?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I boy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then I prethee be merry, thy wit ſhall nere goe ﬂipſhod.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Shalt ſee thy other daughter will vſe thee kindly, for though ſhe is as like this, as a crabbe is like an apple, yet I con, what I can tell.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why what canﬅ thou tell my boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Shee’l taﬅe as like this, as a crab doth to a crab; thou canﬅ not tell why ones noſe ﬅands in the middle of his face?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why to keep his eyes on either ﬁde his noſe, that what a man cannot ſmell out, he may ſpy into.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I did her wrong!

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Canﬅ tell how an Oyﬅer makes his ſhell.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nor I neyther; but I can tell why a ſnayle has a houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why to put his head in, not to giue it away vnto his daughter, and leaue his hornes without a caſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I will forget my nature, ſo kinde a father; bee my horſes ready?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thy Aﬀes are gone about them; the reaſon why the ſeuen ﬅarres are no more then ſeuen, is a pretty reaſon.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Becauſe they are not eight.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Yes, thou wouldﬅ make a good foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To tak’t againe perforce; monﬅer, ingratitude!

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If thou wert my foole Nunckle, Ide haue thee beaten for being olde before thy time.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How’s that?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou ſhouldﬅ not haue beene olde, before thou hadﬅ beene wiſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O let me not be mad ſweete heauen! I would not bee mad, keepe me in temper, I would not bee mad; are the Horſes ready?

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Ready my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come boy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: She that is maid now, and laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a maid long, except things be cut ſhorter.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Baﬆard, and Curan meetes him.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Saue thee Curan.

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: And you ﬁr, I haue beene with your father, and giuen him notice, that the Duke of Cornwall and his Dutcheﬀe will be here with him to night.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: How comes that?

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: Nay I know not, you haue heard of the newes abroad, I meane the whiſperd ones, for there are yet but eare-buﬃng arguments.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Not, I pray you what are they?

speech.speaker: Curan.
speech.line: You may then in time, fare you well ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: The Duke be here to night! the better beﬅ, this weaues it ſelfe perforce into my buﬁineﬀe, my father hath ſet guard to take my brother, & I haue one thing of a queﬁe queﬅion, which

muﬅ aske breefeneﬀe and fortune helpe; brother a word, diſcend brother I ſay, my father watches, O flie this place, intelligence is giuen where you are hid, you haue now the good aduantage of the night, haue you not ſpoken againﬅ the Duke of Cornwall ought, hee’s coming hether now in the night, it’h haﬅe, and Regan with him, haue you nothing ſaide vpon his party againﬅ the Duke of Albaney, aduiſe your―

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I am ſure on’t not a word.

speech.speaker: Baﬅard.
speech.line: I heare my father comming, pardon me in crauing, I muﬅ draw my ſword vpon you, ſeeme to defend your ſelfe, now quit you well, yeeld, come before my father, light heere, heere, flie brother flie, torches, torches, ſo farwell; ſome bloud drawne on me would beget opinion of my more fierce endeuor, I haue ſeene drunkards do more then this in ſport; father, father, ﬅop, ﬅop, no helpe?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Now Edmund, where’s the villaine?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Heere ﬅood he in the darke, his ſharpe ſword out, warbling of wicked charmes, coniuring the Moone to ﬅand his auſpicious Miﬅtris.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: But where is he?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Looke ﬁr, I bleed.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Where is the villaine Edmund?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Fled this way ﬁr, when by no meanes he could―

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Purſue him, go after, by no meanes, what?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Perſwade me to the murder of your Lordſhip, but that I tolde him the reuengiue Gods, gainﬅ Paracides did all their thunders bend, ſpoke with how many ſould and ﬅrong a bond the child was bound to the father; ﬁr, in a fine, ſeeing how lothly oppoﬁte I ﬅood to his vnnaturall purpoſe, with fell motion with his prepared ſword, he charges home my vnprouided body, launcht mine arme; but when he ſaw my beﬅ alarumd ſpirits bold in the quarrels right, rouzd to the encounter, or whether gaﬅed by the noiſe I made, but ſodainly he fled.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Let him flie farre, not in this Land ſhall he remaine vncaught and found; diſpatch, the Noble Duke my maﬅer, my worthy Arch and Patron comes to night, by his authority I will proclaime it, that he which findes him ſhall deſerue our thankes, bringing the murderous caytiffe to the ﬅake, he that conceales him, death.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: When I diﬀwaded him from his intent, and found him pight to do it, with curﬅ ſpeech I threatned to diſcouer him; he replied, Thou vupoﬀeﬃng baﬅard, doﬅ thou thinke, if I would ﬅand againﬅ thee, could the repoſure of any truﬅ, vertue, or worth in thee make thy words faith’d? no: what I ſhould deny, as this I would, I, thogh thou didﬅ produce my very charaƈter, ide turne it all to thy ſuggeﬅion, plot, and damned pretence, and thou muﬅ make a dullard of the world, if they not thought the profits of my death were very pregnant and potentiall ſpurres to make thee ſeeke it.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Strong and faﬅened villaine, would he deny his letter? I neuer got him: harke, the Dukes trumpets, I know not why he comes; all Ports ile barre, the villaine ſhall not ſcape, the Duke muﬅ grant me that: beﬁdes, his piƈture I wil ſend far and neere, that all the kingdome may haue note of him, and of my land, (loyall and naturall boy) ile worke the meanes to make thee capable.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: How now my noble friend, ﬁnce I came hether, which I can call but now, I haue heard ﬅrange newes.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: If it be true, all vengeance comes too ſhort which can purſue the offender; how doﬅ my Lord?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Madam, my old heart is crackt, is crackt.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What, did my fathers godſon ſeeke your life? he whom my father named your Edgar?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I Lady, Lady, ſhame would haue it hid.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Was he not companion with the ryotous Knights that tends vpon my father?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I know not Madam, tis too bad, too bad.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Yes madam, he was.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: No maruaile then though he were ill affeƈted,
Tis they haue put him on the old mans death,
To haue theſe―and waﬅe of this his reuenues:
I haue this preſent euening from my ﬁﬅer
Beene well inform’d of them, and with ſuch cautions,
That if they come to ſoiourne at my houſe, ile not be there.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Nor I, aﬀure thee Regan; Edmund, I heard that you haue ſhewne your father a child-like office.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Twas my duty ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: He did betray his praƈtiſe, and receiued
This hurt you ſee, ﬅriuing to apprehend him.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Is he purſued?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If he be taken, he ſhall neuer more be feard of doing harme, make your owne purpoſe how in my ﬅrength you pleaſe; for you Edmund, whoſe vertue and obedience doth this inﬅant ſo much commend it ſelfe, you ſhall be ours, natures of ſuch deep truﬅ, we ſhall much need, you we firﬅ ſeize on.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I ſhall ſerue you truely, how euer elſe.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: For him I thanke your Grace.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You know not why we came to viﬁte you?

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Thus out of ſeaſon, threatning darke eide night,
Occaﬁons noble Gloceﬅer of ſome prize,
Wherein we muﬅ haue vſe of your aduice,
Our father he hath writ, ſo hath our ﬁﬅer,
Of defences, which I beﬅ thought it fit,
To anſwer from our hand, the ſeurall meﬀengers
From hence attend diſpatch, our good old friend,
Lay comforts to your boſome, & beﬅow your needfull counſell
To our buﬁineﬀe, which craues the inﬅant vſe.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I ſerue you Madam, your Graces are right welcome.

actref.sceneref:
Enter Kent, and Steward.
Steward. Good euen to thee friend, art of the houſe?
Kent. I.
Steward. Where may we ſet our horſes?
Kent. In the mire.
Stew. Prethee if thou loue me, tell me.
Kent. I loue thee not.
Stew. Why then I care not for thee.
Kent. If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
Stew. Why doﬅ thou vſe me thus? I know thee not.
Kent. Fellow I know thee.
Stew. What doﬅ thou know me for?
Kent. A knaue, a raſcall, an eater of broken meates, a baſe, proud, ſhallow, beggerly, three ſhewted hundred pound, filthy worﬅed ﬅocken knaue, a lilly liuer’d aƈtion taking knaue, a whoreſon glaﬀe-gazing ſuperﬁnicall rogue, one trunke inheriting ﬁaue, one that wouldﬅ be a baud in way of good ſeruice, & art nothing but the compoﬁtion of a knaue, begger, coward, pander, and the ſonne and heire of a mungrell bitch, whom I will beate into clamorous whining, if thou deny the leaﬅ ﬁllable of the addition.
Stew. What a monﬅrous fellow art thon, thus to raile on one, that’s neither knowne of thee, nor knowes thee.
Kent. What a brazen fac’ﬅ varlet art thou, to deny thou knoweﬅ me, is it two daies agoe ﬁnce I beate thee, and tript vp thy heeles before the King? draw you rogue, for though it be night the Moon ſhines, ile make a ſop of the Moone-ſhine a’you, draw you whoreſon cullyonly barber-munger, draw.
Stew. Away, I haue nothing to do with thee.
Kent. Draw you raſcall, you bring Letters againﬅ the King, & take Vanity the puppets part, againﬅ the royalty of her father, draw you rogue, or ile ſo carbonado your ſhankes, draw you raſcall, come your wayes.
Stew. Helpe, ho, murther, helpe.
Kent. Strike you ﬂaue, ﬅand rogue, ﬅand you neate ﬂlaue, ﬅrike.
Stew. Helpe ho, murther, helpe.
Enter Edmund with his Rapier drawne, Gloceﬅer, the Duke and Dutcheﬀe.
Baﬅ. How now, what’s the matter?
Ken. With you goodman boy, and you pleaſe come, ile fleaſh you, come on yong maﬅer.
Gloﬅ. Weapons, armes, what’s the matter here?
Duke. Keepe peace vpon your liues, he dies that ﬅrikes againe, what’s the matter?
Reg. The meﬀengers from our ﬁﬅer, and the King.
Duke. What’s your difference, ſpeake?
Stew. I am ſcarſe in breath my Lord.
Kent. No maruaile you haue ſo beﬅir’d your valour, you cowardly raſcall, nature diſclaimes in thee, a Taylor made thee.
Duke. Thou art a ﬅrange fellow, a Taylour make a man.
Kent. I, a taylour ﬁr, a Stone-cutter, or a Painter could not haue made him ſo ill, though he had bene but two houres at the trade.
Gloﬅ. Speake yet, how grew your quarrell?
Stew. This ancient ruffian ﬁr, whoſe life I haue ſpar’d at ſute of his gray-beard.
Kent. Thou whorſon Zed, thou vnneceﬀary letter, my Lord if you will giue me leaue, I will tread this vnboulted villaine into morter, and daube the wals of a Iaques with him; ſpare my gray-beard you wagtaile?
Duke. Peace ﬁr, you beaﬅly knaue you haue no reuerence.
Kent. Yes ﬁr, but anger has a priuiledge.
Duke. Why art thou angry?
Kent. That ſuch a ﬂaue as this ſhould weare a ſword, That weares no honeﬅy, ſuch ſmiling rogues as theſe, Like Rats oft bite thoſe cordes in twaine, Which are to intrench, to inlooſe ſmooth euery paﬃon That in the natures of their Lords rebell, Bring oile to ﬅir, ſnow to their colder moods, Reneag, affirme, and turne their halcion beakes With euery gale and vary of their maﬅers, Knowing nought like daies but following, A plague vpon your Epelipticke viſage, Smoile you my ſpeeches, as I were a foole? Gooſe, if I had you vpon Sarum Plaine, Ide ſend you cackling home to Camulet.
Duke. What, art thou mad olde fellow?
Gloﬅ. How fell you out, ſay that?
Kent. No contraries hold more antipathy, Then I and ſuch a knaue.
Duke. Why doﬅ thou call him knaue, what’s his offence?
Kent. His countenance likes me not.
Duke. No more perchance doth mine, or his, or hers.
Kent. Sir, tis my occupation to be plaine, I haue ſeene better faces in my time, Than ﬅands on any ſhoulder that I ſee Before me at this inﬅant.
Duke. This is a fellow, who hauing beene praiſd For bluntneﬀ, doth affeƈt a ſaucie ruffines, And conﬅraines the garb quite from his nature, He cannot flatter he, he muﬅ be plaine, If not hee’s plaine, theſe kinde of knaues I know, Which in this plainneﬀe harbour more craft, And more corrupter ends, then twenty ﬁlly ducking Obſeruants, that ﬅretch their duties nicely.
Kent. Sir in good ſooth, or in ﬁncere verity, Vnder the allowance of your grand aſpeƈt. Whoſe influence like the wreath of radient fire In flitkering Phœbus front.
Duke. What meanﬅ thou by this?
Kent. To go out of my dialogue which you diſcommend ſo much; I know ﬁr, I am no flatterer, he that beguild you in a plain accent, was a plaine knaue, which for my part I wil not be, thogh I ſhould win your diſpleaſure to entreate me to it.
Duke. What’s the offence you gaue him?
Stew. I neuer gaue him any, it pleaſd the King his maﬅer Very late to ﬅrike at me vpon his miſconﬅruƈtion, When he coniunƈt and flattering his diſpleasure Tript me behinde, being downe, inſulted, raild, And put vpon him ſuch a deale of man, that That worthied him, got praiſes of the King, For him attempting who was ſelfe ſubdued, And in the flechuent of this dread exploit, Drew on me heere againe.
Kent. None of theſe roges & cowards but A’Iax is their foole.
Duke. Bring foorth the ﬅockes ho? You ﬅubborne miſcreant knaue, you vnreuerent bragart, Wee’l teach you.
Kent. I am too olde to learne, call not your ﬅockes for me, I ſerue the King, on whoſe imploiments I was ſent to you, You ſhould do ſmall reſpeƈt, ſhew too bold malice Againﬅ the grace and perſon of my maﬅer, Stopping his Meﬀenger.
Duke. Fetch foorth the ﬅockes; as I haue life and honour, There ſhall he ﬁt till noone.
Reg. Till noone, till night my Lord, and all night too.
Kent. Why Madam, if I were your fathers dog, you could not vſe me ſo.
Reg. Sir, being his knaue, I will.
Duke. This is a fellow of the ſame nature, Our ﬁﬅer ſpeakes off, come, bring away the ﬅockes.
Gloﬅ. Let me beſeech your Grace not to do ſo, His fault is much, and the good King his Maﬅer Will checke him for’t; your purpoſd low correƈtion Is ſuch, as baſeﬅ and ternneﬅ wretches for pilfrings And moﬅ common treſpaﬀes are puniſt with, The King muﬅ take it ill, that hee’s ſo ﬂightly valued In his Meﬀenger, ſhould haue him thus reﬅrained.
Duke Ile anſwer that.
Reg. My ﬁﬅer may receiue it much more worſe, To haue her gentleman abuſed, aﬀaulted For following her affaires, put in his legs, Come my Lord, away.
Exit.
Gloﬅ. I am ſorry for thee friend, tis the Dukes pleaſure, Whoſe diſpoﬁtion all the world well knowes Will not be rubd nor ﬅopt, Ile intreate for thee.
Kent. Pray you do not ﬁr, I haue watcht and trauaild hard, Some time I ſhall ﬂeepe out, the reﬅ Ile whiﬅle, A good mans fortune may grow out at heeles, Giue you good morrow.
Gloﬅ. The Duke’s too blame in this, twill be ill tooke.
Exit.
Kent. Good King, that muﬅ approue the common ſaw, Thou out of heauens benediƈtion comeﬅ To the warme Sunne. Approach thou beacon to this vnder globe, That by thy comfortable beames I may Peruſe this letter, nothing almoﬅ ſees my wracke But miſery, I know tis from Cordelia, Who hath moﬅ fortunately bene informed Of my obſcured courſe, and ſhall finde time From this enormious ﬅate, ſeeking to giue Loﬀes their remedies, all weary and ouer-watcht, Take vantage heauy eies not to behold This ſhamefull lodging; Fortune goodnight, Smile, once more turne thy wheele.
He ﬂeepes.
Enter Edgar.
Edgar, I heare my ſelfe proclaim’d, And by the happy hollow of a Tree, Eſcapt the hunt, no Port is free, no place That guard, and moﬅ vnuſall vigilence Doﬅ not attend my taking while I may ſcape, I will preſerue my ſelfe, and am bethought To take the baſeﬅ and moﬅ pooreﬅ ſhape, That euer penury in contempt of man, Brought neere to beaﬅ; my face ile grime with filth, Blanket my loines, elſe all my haire with knots, And with preſented nakednes out-face The winde, and perſecution of the skie, The Country giues me proofe and preﬁdent Of Bedlam beggers, who with roring voices, Strike in their numb’d and mortified bare Armes, Pins, wooden prickes, nailes, ſprigs of roſemary, And with this horrible obieƈt from low ſeruice, Poore pelting villages, ſheep-coates, and milles, Sometime with lunaticke bans, ſometime with praiers Enforce their charity, poore Turlygod, poore Tom, That’s ſomething yet, Edgar I nothing am.
Exit.
Enter King and a Knight.
Lear. Tis ﬅrange that they ſhould ſo depart from hence, And not ſend backe my meﬀenger.
Knight. As I learn’d, the night before there was No purpoſe of his remoue.
Kent. Haile to thee noble Maﬅer.
Lear. How, mak’ﬅ thou this ſhame thy paﬅime?
Foole. Ha, ha, looke he weares crewell garters, Horſes are tide by the heeles, dogs and beares By the necke, munkies by the loines, and men By the legs, when a man’s ouer-luﬅy at legs, hen he weares wooden neather-ﬅockes.
Lear. What’s he, that hath ſo much thy place miﬅooke to ſet thee here?
Kent. It is both he and ſhe, your ſonne and daughter.
Lear. No.
Kent. Yes.
Lear. No I ſay,
Kent. I ſay yea.
Lear. No, no, they would not.
Kent. Yes they haue.
Lear. By Iupiter I ſweare no, they durﬅ not do’t, They would not, could not do it, tis worſe then murder, To do vpon reſpeƈt ſuch violent out-rage, Reſolue me with all modeﬅ haﬅe, which way Thou maiﬅ deſerue, or they purpoſe this vſage, Comming from vs.
Kent. My Lord, when at their home I did commend your Highneﬀe Letters to them, Ere I was riſen from the place that ſhewed My duty kneeling, came there a reeking Poﬅe, Stewd in his haﬅe, halfe breathleﬀe, panting forth From Gonorill his Miﬅris, ſalutations, Deliuered letters ſpite of intermiﬃon, Which preſently they read: on whoſe contents They ſummond vp their men, ﬅraight tooke horſe, Commanded me to follow, and attend the leiſure Of their anſwer, gaue me cold lookes, And meeting heere the other Meﬀenger, Whoſe welcome I perceiu’d had poiſoned mine, Being the very fellow that of late Diſplaid ſo ſawcily againﬅ your Highneﬀe, Hauing more man then wit about me, drew; He raiſed the houſe with loud and coward cries, Your ſonne and daughter found this treſpaﬀe worth This ſhame which here it ſuffers.
Lear. O how this mother ſwels vp toward my heart, Hiﬅorica paﬃo downe thou climing ſorrow, Thy element’s below, where is this daughter?
Kent. With the Earle ﬁr within.
Lear. Follow me not, ﬅay there.
Knight. Made you no more offence then what you ſpeake of?
Kent. No, how chance the King comes with ſo ſmall a traine?
Foole. If thou hadﬅ beene ſet in the ﬅockes for that queﬅion, thou hadﬅ well deſerued it.
Kent. Why foole?
Foole. Wee’l ſet thee to ſchoole to an Ant, to teach thee ther’s no labouring in the winter, all that follow their noſes, are led by their eyes, but blinde men, and there’s not a noſe among a hundred, but can ſmell him that’s ﬅincking; let goe thy hold when a great wheele runs downe a hill, leaﬅ it breake thy necke with following it, but the great one that goes vp the hill, let him draw thee after, when a wiſe man giues thee better counſell, giue mee mine againe, I would haue none but knaues follow it, ﬁnce a foole giues it. That Sir that ſerues for gaine, And followes but for forme; Will packe when it begins to raine, And leaue thee in the ﬅorme. But I will tarry, the foole will ﬅay, And let the wiſe man flie: The knaue turnes foole that runnes away, The foole no knaue perdy.
Kent. Where learnt you this foole?
Foole. Not in the ﬅockes.
Enter Lear and Gloceﬅer.
Lear. Deny to ſpeake with me? th’are ﬁcke, th’are weary, They traueld hard to night, meare Iuﬅice, I the images of reuolt and flying off, Fetch me a better anſwer.
Gloﬅ. My deare Lord, you know the fiery quality of the Duke, how vnremoueable and fixt he is in his owne courſe.
Lear. Veangeance, death, plague, confuﬁon, what fiery quality; why Gloceﬅer, Gloceﬅer, ide ſpeake with the Duke of Cornewall, and his wife.
Gloﬅ. I my good Lord.
Lear. The King would ſpeake with Cornwall, the deare father Would with his daughter ſpeake, commands her ſeruice, Fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that Lear, No but not yet, may be he is not well, Infirmity doth ﬅill negleƈt all office, where to our health Is bound, we are not our ſelues, when nature being oppreﬅ, Commands the minde to ſuffer with the body; ile forbeare, And am fallen out with my more headier will, To take the indiſposed and ﬁckly fit, for the ſound man, Death on my ﬅate, wherefore ſhould he ﬁt here? This aƈte perſwades me, that this remotion of the Duke & her Is praƈtiſe, onely giue me my ſeruant foorth; Tell the Duke and’s wife, Ile ſpeake with them Now preſently, bid them come forth and heare me, Or at their chamber doore Ile beate the drum, Till it cry ﬂeepe to death.
Gloﬆ. I would haue all well betwixt you.
Lear. O my heart! my heart.
Foole. Cry to it Nunckle, as the Cockney did to the Eeles, when ſhe put them vp i’th paﬅe aliue, ſhe rapt vm ath coxcombs with a ﬅicke, and cryed downe wantons, downe; twas her brother, that in pure kindneﬀe to his horſe, butterd his hay.
Enter Duke and Regan.
Lear. Good morrow to you both.
Duke. Haile to your Grace.
Reg. I am glad to ſee your Highneﬀe.
Lear. Regan, I thinke you are,I know what reaſon I haue to thinke ſo; if thou ſhouldﬅ not be glad, I would diuorce me from thy mothers toombe, Sepulchring an adultereﬀe, yea, are you free? Some other time for that. Beloued Regan, Thy ﬁﬅer is naught, ô Regan ſhe hath tied Sharpe tooth’d vnkindneﬀe, like a vulture heere. I can ſcarſe ſpeake to thee, thou’t not beleeue, Of how depriued a quality, O Regan.
Reg. I pray ﬁr take patience, I haue hope You leﬀe know how to value her deſert, Then ſhe to ﬂacke her duty.
Lear. My curſes on her.
Reg. O ﬁr, you are olde, Nature on you ﬅands on the very verge of her Confine, You ſhould be ruled and led by ſome diſcretion, That diſcernes your ﬅate better then you your ſelfe, Therefore I pray, that to our ﬁﬅer you do make returne, Say you haue wrongd her ﬁr.
Lear. Aske her forgiueneﬀe, Do you marke how this becomes the houſe? Deare daughter, I confeﬀe that I am old, Age is vnneceﬀary, on my knees I beg, That you’l vouchſafe me rayment, bed and food.
Reg. Good ﬁr no more, theſe are vnﬁghtly tricks, Returne you to my ﬁﬅer.
Lear. No Regan, She hath abated me of halfe my traine, Lookt backe vpon me, ﬅroke me with her tongue, Moﬅ ſerpent-like vpon the very heart, All the ﬅor’d vengeances of heauen fall on her ingratefull top, Strike her young bones, you taking aires with lamneﬀe.
Duke. Fie, fie ﬁr.
Lear. You nimble lightnings dart your blinding flames Into her ſcornfull eies, infeƈt her beauty, You Fen fuckt fogs, drawne by the powerfull Sunne, To fall and blaﬅ her pride.
Reg. O the bleﬅ Gods, ſo will you wiſh on me, When the raſh mood―
Lear. No Regan, thou ſhalt neuer haue my curſe, The tender heﬅed nature ſhall not giue thee ore To harſhnes, her eies are fierce, but thine do comfort & not burn Tis not in thee to grudge my pleaſures, to cut off my traine, To bandy haﬅy words, to ſcant my ﬁzes, And in concluﬁon, to oppoſe the bolt Againﬅ my comming in, thou better knoweﬅ The offices of nature, bond of child-hood, Effeƈts of curteﬁe, dues of gratitude, Thy halfe of the kingdome, haﬅ thou not forgot Wherein I thee endowed.
Reg. Good ﬁr to the purpoſe.
Lear. Who put my man i’th ﬅockes?
Duke. What trumpets that?
Enter Steward.
Reg. I know’t my ﬁﬅers, this approues her letters, That ſhe would ſoone be here, is your Lady come?
Lear. This is a ﬂaue, whoſe eaﬁe borrowed pride Dwels in the fickle grace of her he followes, Out varlet, from my ﬁght.
Duke. What meanes your Grace?
Enter Gonorill.
Gon. Who ﬅrucke my ſeruant? Regan I haue good hope Thou didﬅ not know ant.
Lear. Who comes here? O heauens! If you do loue olde men, if you ſweet ſway alow Obedience, if your ſelues are old, make it your cauſe, Send downe and take my part; Art not aſham’d to looke vpon this beard? O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?
Gon. Why not by the hand ﬁr, how haue I offended? All’s not offence that indiſcretion findes, And dotage tearmes ſo.
Lear. O ﬁdes, you are too tough, Will you yet hold? how came my man i’th ﬅockes?
Duke. I ſet him there, but his owne diſorders Deſeru’d much leﬀe aduancement.
Lear. You; did you?
Reg. I pray you father being weake, ſeeme ſo, If till the expiration of your moneth, You will returne and ſoiourne with my ﬁﬅer, Diſmiﬃng halfe your traine, come then to me, I am now from home, and out of that prouiﬁon Which ſhall be needfull for your entertainment.
Lear. Returne to her, and fifty men diſmiﬅ? No, rather I abiure all roofes, and chuſe To wage againﬅ the enmity of the ayre, To be a Comrade with the Wolfe and Owle, Neceﬃties ſharpe pinch, returne with her: Why the hot blood in France, that dowerles Tooke our yongeﬅ borne, I could as well be brought To knee his Throne, and Squire-like penﬁon beg, To keep baſe life afoote; returne with her? Perſwade me rather to be ﬂaue and ſumpter To this deteﬅed groome.
Gon. At your choiſe ﬁr. .
Lear. Now I prethee daughter do not make me mad, I will not trouble thee my childe, farwell, Wee’l no more meete, no more ſee one another. But yet thou art my fleſh, my bloud, my daughter, Or rather a diſeaſe that lies within my fleſh Which I muﬅ needs call mine, thou art a byle, A plague ſore, an imboﬀed carbuncle in my Corrupted bloud, but Ile not chide thee, Let ſhame come when it will, I do not call it, I do not bid the thunder-bearer ſhoote, Nor tell tales of thee to high iudging Ioue, Mend when thou canﬅ, be better at thy leiſure, I can be patient, I can ﬅay with Regan, I and my hundred Knights.
Reg. Not altogether ſo ﬁr, I looke not for you yet, Nor am prouided for your fit welcome, Giue eare to my ﬁﬅer, for thoſe That mingle reaſon with your paﬃon, Muﬅ be content to thinke you are old, and ſo, But ſhe knowes what ſhe does.
Lear. Is this well ſpoken now?
Reg. I dare auouch it ﬁr, what fifty followers, Is it not well? what ſhould you need of more, Yea or ſo many, ﬁth that both charge and danger Speakes gainﬅ ſo great a number, how in a houſe Should many people vnder two commands Hold amity, tis hard, almoﬅ impoﬃble.
Gon. Why might not you my Lord receiue attendance From thoſe that ſhe cals ſeruants, or from mine?
Reg. Why not my Lord? if then they chancﬅ to ﬂacke you, We could controle them; if you will come to me, (For now I ſpie a danger) I entreate you To bring but fiue and twenty to no more Will I giue place, or notice.
Lear. I gaue you all.
Reg. And in good time you gaue it.
Lear. Made you my guardians, my depoﬁtaries, But kept a reſeruation to be followed With ſuch a number, what, muﬅ I come to you With fiue and twenty, Regan, ſaid you ſo?
Reg. And ſpeak’t againe my Lord, no more with me.
Lear. Thoſe wicked creatures yet do ſeeme well-fauour’d When others are more wicked, not being the worﬅ, Stands in ſome ranke of praiſe, Ile go with thee, Thy fifty yet doth double fiue and twenty, And thou art twice her loue.
Gon. Heare me my Lord; What need you fiue and twenty, ten, or fiue, To follow in a houſe, where twice ſo many Haue a command to tend you?
Regan. What needs one?
Lear. O reaſon not the deed, our baſeﬅ beggers Are in the pooreﬅ thing ſuperfluous, Allow not nature more then nature needs, Mans life’s as cheap as beaﬅs; thou art a Lady, If onely to go warme were gorgious, Why nature needs not what thou gorgious weareﬅ, Which ſcarſely keepes thee warme, but for true need, You heauens giue me that patience, patience I need, You ſee me heere (you Gods) a poore old fellow, As full of greefe as age, wretched in both, If it be you that ﬅirres theſe daughters hearts Againﬅ their Father, foole me not too much, To beare it lamely, touch me with noble anger, O let not womens weapons, water drops Staine my mans cheekes, no you vnnaturall hags, I will haue ſuch reuenges on you both, That all the world ſhall―I will do ſuch things, What they are, yet I know not, but they ſhall be The terrors of the earth; you thinke ile weepe, No, ile not weepe, I haue full cauſe of weeping, But this heart ſhall breake in a thouſand flowes Ere ile weepe; ô foole, I ſhall go mad.
Exeunt Lear, Gloceﬅter, Kent, and Foole.
Duke. Let vs withdraw, twill be a ﬅorme.
Reg. This houſe is little, the old man and his people, Cannot be well beﬅowed.
Gon. Tis his owne blame hath put himſelfe from reﬅ, And muﬅ needs taﬅe his folly.
Reg. For his particular, ile receiue him gladly, But not one follower.
Duke. So am I purposſd, where is my Lord of Gloceﬆer?
Enter Gloceﬅer.
Reg. Followed the old man forth, he is return’d.
Glo. The King is in high rage, and will I know not whether.
Reg. Tis good to giue him way, he leads himſelfe.
Gon. My Lord, entreate him by no meanes to ﬅay.
Glo. Alacke, the night comes on, and the bleake windes Do ſorely ruﬀel, for many miles about there’s not a buſh.
Reg. O ﬁr, to wilfull men, The iniuries that they themſelues procure, Muﬅ be their ſchoole-maﬅers, ſhut vp your doores, He is attended with a deſperate traine, And what they may inceſe him too, being apt, To haue his eare abuſed, wiſedome bids feare.
Duke. Shut vp your doores my Lord, tis a wilde night, My Regan counſels well, come out ath ﬅorme.
Exeunt omnes.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Kent and a Gentleman at ſeuerall doores.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What’s heere beﬁde foule weather?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: One minded like the weather, moﬅ vnquietly.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I know you, where’s the King?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Contending with the fretfull Element,
Bids the winde blow the earth into the ſea,
Or ſwell the curled waters boue the maine,
That things might change or ceaſe, teares his white haire,
Which the impetuous blaﬅs with eieleﬀe rage
Catch in their fury, and make nothing of,
Striues in his little world of man to our-ſcorne,
The too and fro confliƈting winde and raine,
This night wherein the cub-drawne Beare would couch,
The Lyon, and the belly pinched Wolfe
Keepe their furre dry, vnbonneted he runnes,
And bids what will take all.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: But who is with him?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: None but the foole, who labours to out-ieﬅ
His heart ﬅrooke iniuries.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir I do know you,
And dare vpon the warrant of my Arte,
Commend a deare thing to you, there is diuiﬁon,
Although as yet the face of it be couer’d
With mutuall cunning, twixt Albany and Cornwall.
But true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this ſcatterd kingdom, who already wiſe in our negligence
Haue ſecret ſee in ſome of our beﬅ Ports,
And are at point to ſhew their open banner,
Now to you, if on my credite you dare build ſo farre,
To make your ſpeed to Douer, you ſhall finde
Some that will thanke you, making iuﬅ report
Of how vnnaturall and bemadding ſorrow
The King hath cauſe to plaine;
I am a Gentleman of blood and breeding,
And from ſome knowledge and aﬀurance,
Offer this Office to you.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I will talke farther with you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No do not,
For confirmation that I much more
Then my outwall, open this purſe and take
What it containes, if you ſhall ſee Cordelia,
As doubt not but you ſhall, ſhew her this ring,
And ſhe will tell you who your fellow is,
That yet you do not know, fie on this ﬅorme,
I will goe ſeeke the King.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Giue me your hand, haue you no more to ſay?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Few words, but to effeƈt more then all yet,
That when we haue found the King,
Ile this way, you that, he that firﬅ lights
On him, hollow the other.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Blow winde and cracke your cheekes, rage, blow
You carterickes, and Hircanios ſpout till you haue drencht
The ﬅeeples, drownd the cockes, you ſulpherous and
Thought executing fires, vaunt-currers to
Oke-cleauing thunder-bolts, ﬁng my white head,
And thou all ſhaking thunder, ſmite flat
The thicke rotundity of the world, cracke natures
Mold, all Germains ſpill at once that make
Ingratefull man.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: O Nunckle, Court holy water in a dry houſe
Is better then this raine water out a doore,
Good Nunckle in, and aske thy daughters bleﬃng,
Here’s a night pitties neyther wiſe man nor foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Rumble thy belly full, ſpit fire, ſpout raine,
Nor raine, winde, thunder, fire, are my daughters,
I taske not you, you Elements with vnkindneﬀe,
I neuer gaue you kingdome, cald you children,
You owe me no ſubſcription; why then let fall your horrible
Pleaſure, here I ﬅand your ﬂaue, a poore, infirme, weake, and
Deſpiſed old man, but yet I call you ſeruile
Miniﬅers, that haue with two pernitious daughters ioyn’d
Your high engendered battell gainﬅ a head ſo old and white
As this, O tis foule.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: He that has a houſe to put his head in, has a good headpeece, the codpeece that will houſe before the head, has any the head and he ſhall lowſe, ſo beggers marry many, the man that makes his toe, what he his heart ſhould make, ſhall haue a corne cry woe, and turne his ﬂeepe to wake, for there was neuer yet faire woman, but ſhe made mouthes in a glaﬀe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, I will be the patterne of all patience,
I will ſay nothing.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marry heere’s grace and a codpis, that’s a wiſeman and a foole.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alaﬀe ﬁr, ﬁt you heere?
Things that loue night, loue not ſuch nights as theſe;
The wrathfull Skies gallow the very wanderer of the
Darke, and makes them keepe their caues,
Since I was man, ſuch ſheetes of fire,
Such burﬅs of horrid thunder, ſuch grones of
Roring winde and raine, I nere remember
To haue heard, mans nature cannot carry
The affliƈtion, nor the force.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let the great Gods that keepe this dreadfull
Thundring ore our heads, finde out their enemies now,
Tremble thou wretch that haﬅ within thee
Vndivulged crimes,, vnwhipt of Iuﬅice,
Hide thee thou bloudy hand, thou periur’d, and
Thou ﬁmular man of vertue that art inceﬅious,
Caytiffe in peeces ſhake, that vnder couert
And conuenient ſeeming, haﬅ praƈtiſed on mans life,
Cloſe pent vp guilts, riue your concealed centers,
And cry theſe dreadfull ſummoners grace,
I am a man more ﬁnd againﬅ their ﬁnning.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alacke bare headed, gracious my Lord, hard by here is a houell, ſome friendſhip will it lend you gainﬅ the tempeﬅ, repoſe you there, whilﬅ I to this hard houſe, more hard then is the ﬅone whereof tis rais’d, which euen but now demanding after me, denide me to come in, returne and force their ſcanted curteﬁe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My wit begins to turne,
Come on my boy, how doﬅ my boy, art cold?
I am cold my ſelfe, where is this ﬅraw my fellow,
The art of our neceﬃties is ﬅrange, that can
Make vilde things precious, come you houell poore,
Foole and knaue, I haue one part of my heart
That ſorrowes yet for thee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: He that has a little tine wit, with hey ho the winde and the raine, muﬅ make content with his fortunes fit, for the raine, it raineth euery day.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: True my good boy, come bring vs to this houell.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Gloceﬅer, and the Baﬅard with lights.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Alacke, alacke, Edmund I like not this
Vnnaturall dealing, when I deﬁred their leaue
That I might pitty him, they tooke from me
The vſe of mine owne houſe, chargd me on paine
Of their diſpleaſure, neither to ſpeake of him,
Entreate for him, nor any way ſuﬅaine him.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Moﬅ ſauage and vnnaturall.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Go too, ſay you nothing, there’s a diuiﬁon betwixt the Dukes,
