And a worſe matter then that, I haue receiued
A letter this night, tis dangerous to be ſpoken,
I haue lockt the letter in my Cloſet, theſe iniuries
The King now beares, will be reuenged home;
There’s part of a power already landed,
We muﬅ incline to the King, I will ſeeke him,
And priuily releeue him; go you and maintaine talke
With the Duke, that my charity be not of him
Perceiued; if he aske for me, I am ill, and gone
To bed, though I die for it, as no leﬀe is threatned me,
The King my old Maﬅer muﬅ be releeued, there is
Some ﬅrange thing toward, Edmund, pray you be carefull.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: This courteﬁe forbid thee, ſhall the Duke inﬅantly know,
And of that letter to, this ſeemes a faire deſeruing,
And muﬅ draw to me that which my father loſes, no leﬀe
Then all, then yonger riſes when the old do fall.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter, the tirrany of the open night’s too ruffe for nature to endure.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me alone.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Wilt breake my heart?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I had rather breake mine owne, good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou thinkﬅ tis much, that this crulentious ﬅorme
Inuades vs to the skin, ſo tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is fixt,
The leﬀer is ſcarſe felt, thou wouldﬅ ſhun a Beare,
But if thy flight lay toward the raging ſea,
Thoud’ﬅ meete the beare it’h mouth, when the mind’s free,
The bodies delicate, the tempeﬅ in my minde,
Doth from my ſences take all feeling elſe,
Saue what beares their filiall ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth ſhould teare this hand
For lifting food to it? but I will puniſh ſure;
No I will weepe no more; in ſuch a night as this!
O Regan, Gonorill, your old kinde father
Whoſe franke heart gaue you all, O that way madneﬀe lies,
Let me ſhunne that, no more of that.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prethee go in thy ſelfe, ſeeke thy owne eaſe,
This tempeﬅ will not giue me leaue to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but Ile go in,
Poore naked wretches, where ſo ere you are
That bide the pelting of this pittileﬀe night,
How ſhall your houſe-leﬀe heads, and vnfed ﬁdes,
Your loopt and windowed raggedneﬀe defend you
From ſeaſons ſuch as theſe, O I haue tane
Too little care of this, take phyﬁcke pompe,
Expoſe thy ſelfe to feele what wretches feele,
That thou maiﬅ ſhake the ſuperflux to them,
And ſhew the heauens more iuﬅ.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Come not in here Nunckle, here’s a ſpirit, helpe me, help me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Giue me thy hand, who’s there?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: A ſpirit, he ſayes his name is poore Tom.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What art thou that doﬅ grumble there in the ﬅraw? come foorth.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Away, the foule fiend followes me, through the ſharpe hathorne blowes the cold winde, goe to thy cold bed & warme thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Haﬅ thou giuen all to thy two daughters, and art thou come to this?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Who giues any thing to poore Tom, whom the foule fiend hath led through fire, and throgh foord, and whirli-poole, ore bog and quagmire, that has laide kniues vnder his pillow, & halters in his pue, ſet ratsbane by his pottage, made him proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horſe ouer foure incht bridges, to courſe his owne ſhadow for a traitor, bleﬀe thy fiue wits, Toms a cold, bleﬀe thee from whirle-windes, ﬅarre-bluﬅing, & taking, do poore Tom ſome charity, whom the foule fiend vexes, there could I haue him now, and there, and there againe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What, his daughters brought him to this paﬀe,
Couldﬅ thou ſaue nothing? didﬅ thou giue them all?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nay he reſerued a blanket, elſe wee had beene all ſhamed.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
Hang fated ore mens faults, fall on thy daughters.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: He hath no daughters ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Death traitor, nothing could haue ſudued nature
To ſuch a lowneﬀe, but his vnkinde daughters,
Is it the faſhion that diſcarded fathers,
Should haue thus little mercy on their fleſh,
Iudicious puniſhment, twas his fleſh
Begot thoſe Pelicane daughters.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Pilicock ſate on pelicocks hill, a lo lo lo.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: This cold night will turne vs all to fooles & madmen.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Take heed of the foule fiend, obey thy parents, keepe thy words iuﬅly, ſweare not, commit not with mans ſworne ſpouſe, ſet not thy ſweet heart on proud array; Toms a cold.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What haﬅ thou beene?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A ſeruing man, proud in heart and minde, that curlde my haire, wore gloues in my cap, ſerued the luﬅ of my miﬅtris heart, and did the aƈte of darkneﬀe with her, ſwore as many oaths as I ſpake words, and broke them in the ſweete face of heauen, one that ﬂept in the contriuing of luﬅ, and wak’t to do it, wine loued I deepely, dice dearely, and in woman, out paramord the Turke, falſe of heart, light of eare, bloudy of hand, hog in ﬂoth, Fox in ﬅealth, Wolfe in greedineﬀe, Dog in madneﬀe, Lyon in prey, let not the creeking of ſhooes, nor the ruﬂings of ﬁlkes betray thy poore heart to women, keepe thy foote out of brothell, thy hand out of placket, thy pen from lenders booke, and defie the foule fiend, ﬅill through the hathorne blowes the colde winde, hay no on ny, Dolphin my boy, my boy, ceaſe let him trot by.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why thou wert better in thy graue, then to anſwer with thy vncouered body this extremity of the skies; is man no more but this? conﬁder him well, thou oweﬅ the worme no ﬁlke, the beaﬅ no hide, the ſheep no wooll, the cat no perfume, he’rs three ones are ſophiﬅicated, thou art the thing it ſelfe, vnaccomodated man is no more but ſuch a poore bare forked Animal as thou art, off, off you leadings, come on be true.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prithee Nunckle be content, this is a naughty night to ſwim in, now a little fire in a wilde field, were like an old lechers heart, a ſmall ſparke, all the reﬅ in body colde, looke here comes a walking fire.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is the foule fiend Sirberdegibit, he begins at curfue, and walks till the firﬅ cocke, he gins the web, the pinqueuer the eye, and makes the hart lip, mildewes the white wheate, & hurts the poore creature of earth, ſwithald footed thrice the olde anelthu night Moore and her nine fold bid her, O light and her troth plight and arint thee, with arint thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: How fares your Grace?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What’s he?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Whoſe there? what iﬅ you ſeeke?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: What are you there? your names?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom, that eates the ſwimming frog, the toade, the toade pold, the wall-wort, and the water, that in the fruite of his heart, when the foule fiend rages,

Eates cowdung for ſallets, ſwallowes the old rat, and the ditchdog, drinkes the greene mantle of the ﬅanding poole, who is whipt from tything to tything, and ﬅock-puniſht and impriſoned, who hath had three ſutes to his backe, ﬁxe ſhirts to his body, horſe to ride, and weapon to weare.
But Mice and Rats and ſuch ſmall Deere,
Hath beene Toms food for ſeuen long yeare.
Beware my follower, peace ſnulbug, peace thou fiend.

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: What, hath your Grace no better company?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The Prince of darknes is a Gentleman, modo hee’s called, and ma hu―

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Our fleſh and bloud is growne ſo vilde my Lord, that it doth hate what gets it.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Toms a colde.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Go in with me, my duty cannot ſuffer to obey in al your daughters hard commands, though their iniunƈtion be to barre my doores, and let this tyranous night take hold vpon you, yet haue I venter’d to come ſeeke you out, and bring you where both food and fire is ready.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Firﬅ let me talke with this Philoſopher;
What is the cauſe of thunder?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My good Lord take his offer, go into the houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile talke a word with this moﬅ learned Theban; what is your ﬅudy?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How to preuent the fiend, and to kill vermine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me aske you one word in priuate.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Importune him to goe my Lord, his wits begin to vnſetle.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Canﬅ thou blame him?
His daughters ſeeke his death. O that good Kent,
He ſaid it would be thus, poore baniſt man,
Thou ſaiﬅ the King growes mad, ile tell thee friend,
I am almoﬅ mad my ſelfe; I had a ſonne
Now out-lawed from my bloud, he ſought my life
But lately, very late, I lou’d him friend,
No father his ſonne dearer, truth to tell thee,
The greefe has craz’d my wits.
What a night’s this? I do beſeech your Grace.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O cry you mercy noble Philoſopher, your company.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tom’s a cold.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: In fellow there, into th’houell, keepe thee warme.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come, let’s in all.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This way my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: With him I will keepe ﬅill, with my Philoſopher.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord ſooth him, let him take the fellow.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Take him you on.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sirra come on, go along with vs.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come good Athenian.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: No words, no words, huſh.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Childe Rowland, to the darke towne come,
His word was ﬅill fye, fo, and fum,
I ſmell the bloud of a Britiſh man.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will haue my reuenge ere I depart the houſe.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: How my Lord I may be cenſured, that nature thus giues way to loyalty, ſome-thing feares me to thinke of.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I now perceiue it was not altogether your brothers euil diſpoﬁtion made him ſeeke his death, but a prouoking merit, ſet a worke by a reproueable badneﬀe in himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: How malicious is my fortune, that I muﬅ repent to bee iuﬅ? this is the Letter he ſpoke off, which approues him an intelligent partie to the aduantages of France, O heauens, that his treaſon were, or not I the deteƈter.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Go with me to the Dutches.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: If the matter of this paper be certaine, you haue mighty buﬁneﬀe in hand.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: True or falſe, it hath made thee Earle of Gloceﬅer, ſeeke out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehenﬁon.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: If I finde him comforting the King, it will ﬅuffe his ſuſpition more fully, I will perſeuere in my courſe of loyalty, thogh the confliƈt be ſore betweene that and my bloud.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will lay truﬅ vpon thee, and thou ſhalt finde a dearer father in my loue.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Gloceﬅer, Lear, Kent, Foole, and Tom.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Here is better then the open ayre, take it thankfully, I will peece out the comfort with what addition I can, I will not be long from you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: All the power of his wits haue giuen way to impatience, the Gods deſerue your kindneﬀe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Fretereto cals me, and tels me Nero is an angler in the lake of darkneﬀe, pray innocent beware the foule fiend.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prethee Nunckle tell me, whether a mad man may bee a Gentleman or a Yeoman.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A King, a King, to haue a thouſand with red burning ſpits come hiﬃng in vpon them.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The foule fiend bites my backe.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: Hee’s mad that truﬅs in the tameneﬀe of a Wolfe, a horſes health, a boyes loue, or a whores oath.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: It ſhall be done, I will arraigne them ﬅraight,
Come ﬁt thou heere moﬅ learned Iuﬅice,
Thou ſapient ﬁr, ﬁt heere, now you ſhee Foxes―

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Looke where he ﬅands and glars, wantﬅ thou eies at triall madam, come ore the broome Beﬀ;y to me.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Her boat hath a leake, and ſhe muﬅ not ſpeak,
Why ſhe dares not come ouer to thee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The foule fiend haunts poore Tom in the voyce of a nightingale, Hoppedance cries in Toms belly for two white herring,
Croke not blacke Angell, I haue no food for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: How do you ﬁr? ﬅand you not ſo amaz’d, will you lie downe and reﬅ vpon the Cuſhions?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile ſee their triall firﬅ, bring in their euidence, thou robbed man of iuﬅice take thy place, & thou his yoke-fellow of equity, bench by his ﬁde, you are o’th commiﬃon, ﬁt you too.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Let vs deale iuﬅly ﬂeepeﬅ or wakeﬅ thou iolly ſhepheard,
Thy ſheepe bee in the corne, and for one blaﬅ of thy minikin mouth, thy ſheepe ſhall take no harme, Pur the cat is gray.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Arraigne her firﬅ, tis Gonorill, I here take my oath before this honorable aﬀembly ſhe kickt the poore King her father.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: Come hither Miﬅreﬀe, is your name Gonorill.

speech.speaker: Lear
speech.line: She cannot deny it.

speech.speaker: Foole
speech.line: Cry you mercy, I tooke you for a ioynt ﬅoole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And heres another whoſe warpt lookes proclaime
What ﬅore her heart is made an, ﬅop her there,
Armes, armes, ſword, fire, corruption in the place,
Falſe Iuﬅicer, why haﬅ thou let her ſcape?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bleﬀe thy fiue wits.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O pitty ﬁr, where is the patience now,
That you ſo oft haue boaﬅed to retaine.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: My teares begin to take his part ſo much,
They’l marre my counterfeting.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The little dogs and all,
Trey, Blanch, and Sweet-hart, ſee they barke at me.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tom will throw his head at them, auaunt you curs.

Be thy mouth, or blacke or white, tooth that poiſons if it bite, Maﬅiue, Gray-hound, Mungrel, Grim-hound, or Spaniell, Brach or Him, Bobtaile tike, or Trundle-taile, Tom will make them weepe and waile. For with throwing thus my head, dogs leape the hatch, and all are fled, loudla doodla, come march to wakes, and faires, and market townes, poore Tom thy horne is dry.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then let them anotomize Regan, ſee what breeds about her,
Hart is there any cauſe in nature that makes this hardneﬀe;
You ﬁr, I entertaine you for one of my hundred,
Onely I do not like the faſhion of your garment; you’l ſay
They are Perﬁan attire, but let them be changed.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now good my Lord lie here a while.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Make no noiſe, make no noiſe, draw the Curtaines, ſo, ſo, ſo, wee’l go to ſupper in the morning, ſo, ſo, ſo.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Come hither friend, where is the King my maﬅer?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here ﬁr, but trouble him not, his wits are gone.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Good friend, I prethee take him in thy armes,
I haue ore-heard a plot of death vpon him,
There is a Litter ready, lay him in it, and driue towards Douer, friend,
Where thou ſhalt meete both welcome and proteƈtion; take vp thy maﬅer,
If thou ſhouldﬅ dally halfe an houre, his life with thine,
And all that offer to defend him, ﬅand in aﬀured loﬀe,
Take vp to keepe, and follow me that will to ſome prouiﬁon,
Giue thee quicke conduƈt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Oppreﬀed nature ﬂeepes,
This reﬅ might yet haue balmed thy broken ﬁnewes,
Which if conuenience will not allow, ﬅand in hard cure,
Come helpe to beare thy Maﬅer, thou muﬅ not ﬅay behinde.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Come, come, away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: When we our betters ſee bearing our woes,
We ſcarſely thinke our miſeries our foes.
Who alone ſuffers, moﬅ i’th minde,
Leauing free things and happy ſhowes behinde,
But then the minde much ſufferance doth ore-skip,
When griefe hath mates, and bearing fellowſhip:
How light and portable my paine ſeemes now,
When that which makes me bend, makes the King bow:
He childed as I fatherd, Tom away,
Marke the high noiſes, and thy ſelfe bewray,
When falſe opinion, whoſe wrong thoughts defile thee,
In thy iuﬅ proofe repeals and reconciles thee,
What will hap more to night, ſafe ſcape the King,
Lurke, lurke.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Cornwall, Regan, Gonorill, and Baﬅard.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Poﬅe ſpeedily to my Lord your husband, ſhew him this Letter,
The army of France is landed, ſeeke out the villaine Gloceﬅer.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Hang him inﬅantly.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Plucke out his eyes.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leaue him to my diſpleaſure, Edmund keepe you our ﬁﬅer company. The reuenge we are bound to take vpon your traiterous father, are not fit for your beholding, aduiſe the Duke where you are going to a moﬅ feﬅuant preparation, wee are bound to the like.
Our poﬅe ſhall be ſwift and intelligence betwixt vs;
Farwell dear ﬁﬅer, farwell my Lord of Gloceﬅer,
How now, wheres the King?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My Lord of Gloceﬅer hath conueyed him hence,

Some fiue or ﬁxe and thirty of his Knights hot queﬅrits after him, met him at gate, who with ſome other of the Lords dependants are gone with him towards Douer, where they boaﬅ to haue well armed friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Get horſes for your miﬅris.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Farwell ſweet Lord and ﬁﬅer.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Edmund farwell: go ſeeke the traitor Gloceﬅer,
Pinion him like a theefe, bring him before vs,
Though we may not paﬀe vpon his life
Without the forme of iuﬅice, yet our power
Shall do a curteﬁe to our wrath, which men may blame
But not controle; who’s there, the traitor?

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Gloceﬅer, brought in by two or three.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ingratefull Fox tis he.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Binde faﬅ his corky armes.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: What meanes your Graces, good my friends conﬁder,
You are my gueﬅs, do me no foule play friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Binde him I ſay.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Hard, hard; O filthy traitor!

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Vnmercifull Lady as you are, I am true.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: To this chaire binde him, villaine thou ſhalt find―

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: By the kinde Gods tis moﬅ ignobly done, to plucke me by the beard.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: So white, and ſuch a Traitor,

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: Naughty Lady, theſe haires which thou doﬅ rauiſh frō my chin,
Will quicken and accuſe thee, I am your hoﬅ:
With robbers hands, my hoſpitable fauours
You ſhould not ruffell thus, what will you do?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Come ﬁr, what letters had you late from France?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Be ﬁmple anſwerer, for we know the truth.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: And what confederacy haue you with the traitors lately footed in the kingdome?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: To whoſe hands haue you ſent the lunaticke king, ſpeak?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I haue a letter gueﬃngly ſet downe,
Which came from one that’s of a neutrall heart,
And not from one oppoſed.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Cunning.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And falſe.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Where haﬅ thou ſent the King?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: To Douer.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer? waﬅ thou not charg’d at perill―

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer? let him firﬅ anſwer that.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I am tide tot’h ﬅake, and I muﬅ ﬅand the courſe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Becauſe I would not ſee thy cruell nayles
Plucke out his poore olde eyes, nor thy fierce ﬁﬅer
In his aurynted fleſh raſh boriſh phangs,
The ſea with ſuch a ﬅorme of his lou’d head
In hell blacke night endur’d, would haue laid vp
And quencht the ﬅeeled fires, yet poore old heart,
He holpt the heauens to rage,
If Wolues had at thy gate heard that dearne time,
Thou ſhouldﬅ haue laid, good Porter turne the key,
All cruels elſe ſubſcrib’d, but I ſhall ſee
The winged vengeance ouertake ſuch children.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: See’t ſhalt thou neuer, fellowes hold the chaire,
Vpon thoſe eies of thine, Ile ſet my foote.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: He that will thinke to liue till he be old―
Giue me ſome helpe, ô cruell, ô ye Gods!

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: One ﬁde will mocke another, tother to.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: If you ſee vengeance―

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Hold your hand my Lord,
I haue ſeru’d you euer ﬁnce I was a childe,
But better ſeruice haue I neuer done you, then now to bid you hold.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: How now you dog.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: If you did weare a beard vpon your chin, ide ſhake it on this quarrell, what do you meane?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: My villaine.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Why then come on, and take the chance of anger.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Giue me thy ſword, a peſant ﬅand vp thus.

sceneref.stagedir: She takes a ſword, and runs at him behinde.

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Oh I am ﬂaine my Lord, yet haue you one eye left to ſee ſome miſchiefe on him, oh!

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leaﬅ it ſee more, preuent it, out vilde Ielly,
Where is thy luﬅer now?

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: All darke and comfortles, wheres my ſonne Edmund?
Edmund vnbridle all the ſparkes of nature, to quit this horrid aƈte.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Out villaine, thou calﬅ on him that hates thee, it was hee that made the ouerture of thy treaſons to vs, who is too good to pitty thee.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: O my follies, then Edgar was abuſed,
Kinde Gods forgiue me that, and proſper him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Goe thruﬅ him out at gates, and let him ſmell his way to Douer, how iﬅ my Lord? how looke you?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I haue receiued a hurt, follow me Lady,
Turne out that eyleﬀe villaine, throw this ﬂaue vpon
The dunghill, Regan I bleed apace, vntimely
Comes this hurt, giue me your arme.

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Ile neuer care what wickedneﬀe I do,
If this man come to good.

speech.speaker: 2. Seruant.
speech.line: If ſhe liue long, and in the end meet the old courſe of death, women will all turne monﬅers.

speech.speaker: 1 Ser.
speech.line: Let’s follow the old Earle, and get the bedlam
To lead him where he would, his rogiſh madneﬀe
Allowes it ſelfe to any thing.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Goe thou, ile fetch ſome flaxe and whites of egges to apply to his bleeding face, now heauen helpe him.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemn’d,
Then ﬅill contemn’d and flattered to be worﬅ,
The loweﬅ and moﬅ deieƈted thing of Fortune
Stands ﬅill in experience, luies not in feare,
The lamentable change is from the beﬅ,
The worﬅ returnes to laughter,
Who’s here, my father poorely led, world, world, ô world!
But that thy ﬅrange mutations make vs hate thee,
Life would not yeeld to age.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Gloﬅer led by an olde man.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: O my good Lord, I haue bene your tenant, & your fathers tenant this foureſcore―

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Away, get thee away, good friend be gone,
Thy comforts can do me no good at all,
Thee they may hurt.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Alacke ﬁr, you cannot ſee your way.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: I haue no way, and therefore want no eies,
I ﬅumbled when I ſaw, full oft tis ſeene
Our meanes ſecure vs, and our meere defeƈts
Prooue our commodities; ah deare ſonne Edgar,
The food of thy abuſed fathers wrath,
Might I but liue to ſee thee in my tuch,
Ide ſay I had eyes againe.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: How now, who’s there?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O Gods, who iﬅ can ſay I am at the worﬅ,
I am worſe then ere I was.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Tis poore mad Tom.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: And worſe I may be yet, the worﬅ is not,
As long as we can ſay, this is the worﬅ.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Fellow where goeﬅ?

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: Is it a begger man?

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Mad man, and begger too.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: He has ſome reaſon, elſe he could not beg,
In the laﬅ nights ﬅorme I ſuch a fellow ſaw,
Which made me thinke a man a worme, my ſonne
Came then into my minde, and yet my minde
Was then ſcarſe friends with him, I haue heard more ﬁnce,
As flyes are to’th wanton boyes, are we to’th Gods,
They bit vs for their ſport.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How ſhould this be? bad is the trade that muﬅ play the foole to ſorrow, angring it ſelfe and others; bleﬀe thee maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Gloﬆ.
speech.line: Is that the naked fellow?

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Then prethee get thee gone, if for my ſake
Thou wilt ore-take vs here a mile or twaine
Ith’way to Douer, do it for ancient loue,
And bring ſome couering for this naked ſoule,
Who ile entreate to lead me.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Alacke ﬁr he is mad.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Tis the times plague, when madmen leade the blinde,
Do as I bid thee, or rather do they pleaſure,
Aboue the reﬅ, be gone.

speech.speaker: Old man.
speech.line: Ile bring him the beﬅ parrell that I haue,
Come on’t what will.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Sirra, naked fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Toms a cold, I cannot dance it farther.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Come hither fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bleﬀe thy ſweete eyes, they bleed.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Knowﬅ thou the way to Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Both ﬅile and gate, horſe-way, and foot-path,
Poore Tom hath beene ſcard out of his good wits,
Bleﬀe the good man from the foule fiend,
Fiue fiends haue beene in poore Tom at once,
Of luﬅ, as Obidicut, Hobbididence Prince of dumbneﬀe,
Mahu of ﬅealing, Modo of murder, Stiberdigebit of Mobing,
And Mohing who ﬁnce poﬀeﬀes chambermaids
And waiting women, ſo, bleﬀe thee maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Here take this purſe, thou whom the heauens plagues
Haue humbled to all ﬅrokes, that I am wretched, makes thee
The happier, heauens deale ſo ﬅill,
Let the ſuperfluous and luﬅ-dieted man
That ﬅands your ordinance, that will not ſee
Becauſe he doth not feele, feele your power quickly,
So diﬅribution ſhould vnder exceﬀe,
And each man haue enough: doﬅ thou know Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: There is a cliffe, whoſe high and bending head
Lookes firmely in the confined deepe,
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And ile repaire the miſery thou doﬅ beare,
With ſomething rich about me,
From that place ſhall I no leading need.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me thy arme, poore Tom ſhall lead thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord, I maruaile our milde husband
Not met vs on the way: now where’s your Maﬅer?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madame within, but neuer man ſo chang’d; I tolde him of the Army that was landed, he ſmiled at it, I told him you were coming, his anſwer was, the worſe; of Gloﬅers treachery, and of the loyall ſeruice of his ſonne, when I enformd him, then he cald me for, and told me I had turnd the wrong ﬁde out, what hee ſhould moﬅ deﬁre, ſeemes pleaſant to him, what like offenﬁue.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Then ſhall you go no further.
It is the cowiſh curre of his ſpirit
That dares not vndertake, heel not feele wrongs
Which tye him to an anſwer, our wiſhes on the way
May proue effeƈts, backe Edmund to my brother,
Haﬅen his muﬅers, and conduƈt his powers,
I muﬅ change armes at home, and giue the diﬅaffe
Into my husbands hands; this truﬅy ſeruant
Shall paﬀe betweene vs, ere long you are like to heare
If you dare venter in your owne behalfe
A miﬅtreﬀes coward, weare this ſpare ſpeech,
Decline your head: this kiﬀe if it durﬅ ſpeake,
Would ﬅretch thy ſpirits vp into the ayre;
Conceiue, and faryewell.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Yours in the rankes of death.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: My moﬅ deare Gloﬅer, to thee a womans ſeruices are due,
My foote vſurpes my head.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madame, heere comes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: I haue bene worth the whiﬅle.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: O Gonorill, you are not worth the duﬅ which the winde
Blowes in your face, I feare your diſpoﬁtion,
That nature which contemnes it origin,
Cannot be bordered certaine in it ſelfe,
She that her ſelfe will ﬂiuer and disbranch
From her materiall ſap, perforce muﬅ wither,
And come to deadly vſe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: No more, the text is fooliſh.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Wiſedome and goodneﬀe to the vilde ſeeme vilde,
Filths fauour but themſelues, what haue you done?
Tygers, not daughters, what haue you perform’d?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whoſe reuerence the head-lugd Beare would licke:
Moﬅ barbarous, moﬅ degenerate haue you madded;
Could my good brother ſuffer you to do it?
A man, a Prince, by him ſo benefliƈted,
If that the heauens do not their viﬁble ſpirits
Send quickly downe to tame the vilde offences, it will come
Humanly muﬅ perforce prey on it ſelfe, like monﬅers of the deepe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Milke liuer’d man,
That beareﬅ a cheeke for blowes, a head for wrongs,
Who haﬅ not in thy browes an eie deſeruing thine honour,
From thy ſuffering, that not know’ﬅ fooles, do theſe villains pity
Who are puniſt ere they haue done their miſchiefe,
Where’s thy drum? France ſpreds his banners in our noiſeleﬀe
Land, with plumed helme thy ﬂaier begins threats,
Whiles thou a morall foole ﬁts ﬅill and cries
Alacke why does he ſo?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: See thy ſelfe diuell, proper deformity ſeemes not in the fiend, ſo horrid as in woman.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: O vaine foole.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Thou chang’d and ſelfe-couerd thing, for ſhame
Be-monﬅer not thy feature, wer’t my fitneﬀe
To let theſe hands obey my bloud,
They are apt enough to diﬂecate and teare
Thy fleſh and bones, how ere thou art a fiend,
A woman ſhape doth ſhield thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Marry your man-hood now―

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What newes?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: O my good Lord, the Duke of Cornwalls dead, ﬁaine by his ſeruant, going to put out the other eie of Gloﬅer.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Gloﬅers eyes?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: A ſeruant that he bred, thrald with remorſe,
Oppos’d againﬅ the aƈte, bending his ſword
To his great maﬅer, who thereat enraged,
Flew on him, and amongﬅ them feld him dead,
But not without that harmfull ﬅroke,
Which ﬁnce hath pluckt him after.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: This ſhewes you are aboue your Iuﬅices,
That theſe our neather crimes ſo ſpeedily can venge.
But oh poore Gloceﬅer, loﬅ he his other eye?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Both, both my Lord, this letter Madam craues a ſpeedy
Anſwer, tis from your ﬁﬅer.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: One way I like this well,
But being widow, and my Gloceﬅer with her,
May all the building on my fancy plucke,
Vpon my hatefull life, another way the newes is not ſo tooke,
Ile reade and anſwer.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where was his ſonne when they did take his eies?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Come with my Lady hither.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: He is not here.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No my good Lord, I met him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Knowes he the wickedneﬀe?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I my good Lord, twas he inform’d againﬅ him,
And quit the houſe on purpoſe, that their puniſhment
Might haue the freer courſe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Gloceﬅer, I liue to thanke thee for the loue
Thou ſhewedﬅ the King, and to reuenge thy eyes;
Come hether friend, tell me what more thou knoweﬅ.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why the King of France is ſo ſuddenly gone backe,
Know you the reaſon?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Something he left imperfeƈt in the ﬅate, which ﬁnce his comming foorth is thought of, which imports to the Kingdom ſo much feare and danger that his perſonall returne was moﬅ required and neceﬀary.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who hath he left behinde him, Generall?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: The Marſhall of France, Monﬁeur la Far.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Did your letters pierce the Queene to any demonﬅration of griefe?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I ſay ſhe tooke them, read them in my preſence,
And now and then an ample teare trild downe
Her delicate cheeke, it ſeemd ſhe was a Queene ore her paﬃon,
Who moﬅ rebell-like, ſought to be King ore her.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O then it moued her.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Not to a rage, patience and ſorrow ﬅreme,
Who ſhould expreﬀe her goodlieﬅ, you haue ſeene
Sun-ſhine and raine at once, her ſmiles and teares,
Were like a better way, thoſe happy ſmilets
That plaid on her ripe lip, ſeeme not to know
What gueﬅs were in her eyes, which parted thence
As pearles from Diamonds dropt; in briefe,
Sorrow would be a rarity moﬅ beloued,
If all could ſo become it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Made ſhe no verball queﬅion?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Faith once or twice ſhe heau’d the name of father
Pantingly foorth, as if it preﬅ her heart,
Cried ﬁﬅers, ﬁﬅers, ſhame of Ladies ﬁﬅers;
Kent. Father, ﬁﬅers, what ith ﬅorme ith night?
Let pitty not be beleeu’d, there ſhe ſhooke
The holy water from her heauenly eyes,
And clamour moiﬅened her, then away ſhe ﬅarted,
To deale with griefe alone.

speech.speaker: Kent,
speech.line: It is the ﬅars, the ﬅars aboue vs gouern our conditions,
Elſe one ſelfe mate and mate could not beget
Such different iﬀues; you ſpoke not with her ﬁnce?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Was this before the King returnd?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No, ﬁnce.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Well ﬁr, the poore diﬅreﬀed Lear’s ith Towne,
Who ſometime in his better tune remembers
What we are come about, and by no meanes will yeeld to ſee his daughter.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Why good ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A ſouerigne ſhame ſo elbowes him, his own vnkindnes
That ﬅript her from his benediƈtion, turnd her
To forraine caſualties, gaue her deare rights
To his dog-hearted daughters; theſe things ﬅing his minde
So venomouﬂy, that burning ſhame detaines him from​Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Alacke poore Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Of Albanies and Cornwals powers you heard not?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Tis ſo they are afoote.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Well ﬁr, ile bring you to our maﬅer Lear,
And leaue you to attend him, ſome deare cauſe
VVill in concealement wrap me vp a while,
VVhen I am knowne aright you ſhall not greeue,
Lending me this acquaintance, I pray you go along with me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Alacke tis he, why he was met euen now,
As mad as the vent ſea, ﬁnging aloud,
Crownd with ranke femiter and furrow weeds,
VVith hor-docks, hemlocke, nettles, coockow-flowers,
Darnell and all the idle weeds that grow
In our ſuﬅaining, Corne, a century is ſent foorth,
And bring him to our eye, what can mans wiſedome do
In the reﬅoring his bereaued ſence? he that can helpe him
Take all my outward worth.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: There is meanes Madame,
Our foﬅer nurſe of nature is repoſe,
The which he lackes, that to prouoke in him
Are many ﬁmples operatiue, whoſe power
Will cloſe the eye of anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: All bleﬅ ſecrets, all you vnpubliſht vertues of the earth,
Spring with my teares, be aidant and remediat
In the good mans diﬅtreﬀe, ſeeke, ſeeke for him,
Leaﬅ his vngouernd rage diﬀolue the life,
That wants the meanes to leade it.

speech.speaker: Meﬀen.
speech.line: Newes Madam, the Britiſh powers are marching hetherward.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: Tis knowne before, our preparation ﬅands
In expeƈtation of them, ô deare Father,
It is thy buﬁneﬀe that I go about, therefore great France,
My mourning and important teares hath pittied,
No blowne ambition doth our armes inﬁte,
But loue, deare loue, and our aged fathers right,
Soone may I heare and ſee him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But are my brothers powers ſet foorth?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Himſelfe in perſon?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam with much ado, your ﬁﬅer’s the better Soldier.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Lord Edmund ſpake not with your Lady at home?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: No Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What might import my ﬁﬅers letter to him?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I know not Lady.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Faith he is poﬅed hence on a ſerious matter,
It was great ignorance, Gloceﬅers eies being out,
To let him liue, where he arriues he moues
All hearts againﬅ vs, and now I thinke is gone,
In pitty of his miſery to diſpatch his nighted life,
Moreouer to deſcrie the ﬅrength of the Army.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I muﬅ needs after him with my Letters

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our troope ſets foorth to morrow, ﬅay with vs,
The wayes are dangerous.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I may not Madam, my Lady charg’d my dutie in this buﬁneﬀe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Why ſhould ſhe write to Edmund? Might not you
Tranſport her purpoſes by word, belike
Something, I know not what, Ile loue thee much,
Let me vnſeale the Letter.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam Ide rather―

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I know your Lady does not loue her husband,
I am ſure of that: and at her late being heere
She gaue ﬅrange aliads, and moﬅ ſpeaking lookes
To Noble Edmund, I know you are of her boſome.

speech.speaker: Stew,
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I ſpeake in vnderﬅanding, for I know’t,
Therefore I do aduiſe you take this note:
My Lord is dead, Edmund and I haue talkt,
And more conuenient is he for my hand,
Then for your Ladies: you may gather more,
If you do finde him, pray you giue him this,
And when your miﬅris heares thus much from you,
I pray deﬁre her call her wiſedome to her, ſo farewell,
If you do chance to heare of that blinde traitor,
Preferment fals on him that cuts him off.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Would I could meet him Madam, I would ſhew
What Lady I do follow.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: When ſhall we come to’th top of that ſame hill?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: You do climbe it vp now, looke how we labour?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Me thinkes the ground is euen.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Horrible ﬅeepe: hearke, do you heare the ſea?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: No truly.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why then your other ſenſes grow imperfeƈt
By your eies anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: So may it be indeed,
Methinkes thy voice is altered, and thou ſpeakﬅ
With better phraſe and matter then thou didﬅ.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Y’are much deceiued, in nothing am I changd,
But in my garments.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Me thinkes y’are better ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Come on ﬁr, here’s the place, ﬅand ﬅill, how fearfull
And dizy tis to caﬅ ones eyes ſo low:
The Crowes and Choughes that wing the midway ayre
Shew ſcarſe ſo groﬀe as beetles, halfe way downe
Hangs one that gathers Sampire, dreadfull trade,
Me thinkes he ſeemes no bigger then his head:
The fiſhermen that walke vpon the beake
Appeare like Mice; and yon tall Anchoring barke
Diminiſht to her cocke; her cocke aboue
Almoﬅ too ſmall for ﬁght. The murmuring ſurge,
That on the vnnumbred idle peebles chafe,
Cannot be heard: it is ſo hie Ile looke no more
Leaﬅ my braine turne, and the deficient ﬁght
Topple downe headlong.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Set me where you ﬅand.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand: you are now within a foot
Of the extreme verge; for all beneath the Moone
Would I not leape vpright.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Let go my hand:
Heere friend’s another purſe in it a Iewell
Well worth a poore mans taking. Fairies and Gods
Proſper it with thee. go thou farther off,
Bid me farewell, and let me heare thee going.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Now fare you well good ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: With all my heart.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why I do trifle thus with his diſpaire, tis done to cure it.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O you mighty Gods,
This world I do renounce, and in your ﬁghts
Shake patiently my great affliƈtion off,
If I could beare it longer, and not fall
To quarrell with your great oppoſeleﬀe wils,
My ſnuffe and loathed part of nature ſhould
Burne it ſelfe out: if Edgar liue, O bleﬀe,
Now fellow fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Gon ﬁr, farewell, and yet I know not how conceite may rob the treaſury of life, when life it ſelfe yeelds to the theft: had he bene where he thought, by this thought had bene paﬅ: Aliue or dead? Ho you ﬁr, heare you ﬁr, ſpeake, thus might hee paﬀe indeed, yet he reuiues, what are you ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Away, and let me dye.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Hadﬅ thou bene ought but goſmore feathers ayre,
So many fadome downe precipitating,
Thou hadﬅ ſhiuerd like an Egge, but thou doﬅ breath,
Haﬅ heauy ſubﬅance, bleedﬅ not, ſpeakﬅ, art found:
Ten Maﬅs at each make not the altitude,
Which thou haﬅ perpendicularly fell,
Thy lifes a miracle, ſpeake yet againe.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: But haue I fallen or no?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: From the dread ſummons of this chalkie borne,
Looke vp a hight; the ſhrill gorg’d Larke ſo farre
Cannot be ſeene or heard, do but looke vp.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Alacke, I haue no eyes:
Is wretchedneﬀe depriu’d that benefite
To end it ſelfe by death? Twas yet ſome comfort,
When miſery could beguile the Tyrants rage,
And fruﬅrate his proud will.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your arme:
Vp, ſo, how feele you your legges? you ﬅand.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Too well, too well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is aboue all ﬅrangeneﬀe:
Vpon the crowne of the cliffe, what thing was that
Which parted from you?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: A poore vnfortunate begger.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: As I ﬅood heere below, methought his eyes
Were two full Moones; a had a thouſand noſes,
Hornes, welkt and waued like the enridged ſea,
It was ſome fiend, therefore thou happy Father
Thinke that the cleereﬅ Gods, who made their honors
Of mens impoﬃbilities, haue preſerued thee.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I do remember now, henceforth Ile beare
Affliƈtion till it do cry out it ſelfe
Enough, enough, and dye: that thing you ſpeake of,
I tooke it for a man: often would he ſay
The fiend, the fiend, he led me to that place.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bare, free, and patient thoughts: but who comes heere,
The ſafer ſenſe will nere accommodate his maiﬅer thus.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, they cannot touch me for coyning, I am the King himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O thou ﬁde piercing ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nature is aboue Art in that reſpeƈt, ther’s your preﬀe-money. That fellow handles his bow like a Crow-keeper, draw me a clothiers yard. Looke, looke, a Mouſe; peace, peace, this toﬅted cheeſe will do it. Ther’s my gantlet, Ile proue it on a Gyant, bring vp the browne bils. O well ﬂowne birde in the ayre.
Hagh, giue the word.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Sweet Margerum.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Paﬀe.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I know that voice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha Gonorill, ha Regan, they flatter’d me like a dogge, and told me I had white haires in my beard, ere the black ones were there; to ſay I and no to all I ſaide: I and no too was no good Diuinity. When the raine came to wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter, when the thunder would not peace at my bidding, there I found them, there I ſmelt them out: goe too, they are not men of their words, they told mee I was euery thing, tis a lye, I am not argue-proofe.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: The tricke of that voyce I doe well remember, iﬅ not the King?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I, euery inch a King: when I do ﬅare ſee how the ſubieƈt quakes: I pardon that mans life, what was thy cauſe, Adulterie? thou ſhalt not dye for adultery: no, the wren goes toot, and the ſmall guilded flye do letcher in my ﬁght; let copulation thriue. For Gloﬅers baﬅard ſon was kinder to his father then my daughters got tweene the lawfull ſheets, toot Luxury, pell mell, for I want ſouldiers. Behold you ﬁmpring dame, whoſe face between her forkes preſageth ſnow, that minces vertue, and do ſhake the head, heare of pleaſures name to ﬁchew, nor the foyled Horﬀe goes toot with a more riotous appetite: downe from the waﬅe they are Centaures, though women all aboue, but to the girdle do the gods inherit, beneath is all the fiends, theres Hell, theres darkneﬀe, theres the ſulphury pit, burning, ſcalding, ﬅench, comſummation, fie, fie, fie, pah, pah: Giue mee an ounce of Ciuet, good Apothecary, to ſweeten my imagination, ther’s money for thee.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O let me kiﬀe that hand.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Here wipe it firﬅ, it ſmels of mortality.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O ruin’d peece of nature, this great world ſhold ſo weare out to naught, do you know me?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I remember thy eyes well enough, doﬅ thou ſquiny on me: no, do thy worﬅ blinde Cupid, Ile not loue: Read thou that challenge, marke the penning on’t.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Were all the letters ſuns I could not ſee one.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I would not take this from report, it is, & my hart breaks at it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Read.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: What, with the caſe of eyes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head nor money in your purſe? your eyes are in a heauy caſe, your purﬀe in a light; yet you ſee how this world goes?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I ſee it feelingly.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: What art mad? A man may ſee how the world goes wiſh no eyes. Looke with thy eares, ſee how yon Iuﬅice railes vppon yon ﬁmple theefe: hearke in thy eare, handy dandy, which is the theefe, which is the Iuﬅice. Thou haﬅ ſeene a farmers dog barke at a begger.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightﬅ behold the great image of Authoritie, a dogge, ſo bad in office. Thou Raſcall Beadle hold thy bloody hand; why doﬅ thou laſh that whore? ﬅrip thine owne backe, thy blood hotly luﬅs to vſe her in that kind for which thou whipﬅ her. The vſurer hangs the cozener, through tattered ragges ſmall vices do appeare, Robes and furd-gownes hides all. Get thee glaﬀe eyes, and like a ſcuruy politician, ſeeme to ſee the things thou doeﬅ not; No, now pull off my boots, harder, harder, ſo.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O matter and impertinency, mixt reaſon in madneﬀe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou wilt weepe my fortune, take my eyes; I know thee well enough, thy name is Gloﬅer, thou muﬅ be patient, we came crying hither: thou knowﬅ the firﬅ time that we ſmel the aire, we waile and cry. I will preach to thee, marke me.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Alack, alack, the day.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: When we are borne, we crie that wee are come to this great ﬅage of fooles: this a good blocke. It were a delicate ﬅratagem to ſhoot a troope of horſe with fell, and when I haue ﬅole vpon theſe ſonnes in law, then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: O here he is, lay hands vpon him ﬁrs.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No reſcue, what a priſoner? I am eene the naturall foole of Fortune: vſe me well, you ſhall haue a ranſom. Let me haue a Chirurgeon, I am cut to’th braines.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You ſhall haue any thing.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No ſeconds, all my ſelfe: why this would make a man of ſalt to vſe his eyes for garden water-pottes, I and laying Autumnes duﬅ.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Good Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I will dye brauely like a Bridegroome. What, I will bee iouiall: Come, come, I am a King my maﬅers, know you that?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You are a royall one, and we obey you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then theres life int, nay if you get it you ſhall get it with running.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: A ﬁght moﬅ pittifull in the meaneﬅ wretch, paﬅ ſpeaking of in a king: thou haﬅ one daughter who redeemes nature from the generall curſe which twaine hath brought her to.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Haile gentle ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Sir ſpeed you, what’s your will?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Do you heare ought of a battell toward?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Moﬅ ſure and vulgar, euery ones heares
That can diﬅinguiſh ſenſe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: But by your fauour, how neeres the other army?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Neere and on ſpeed for’t, the maine deſcries,
Stands on the hourely thoughts.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you ﬁr, thats all.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Though that the Queene on ſpeciall cauſe is heere,
His army is mou’d on.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: You euer gentle gods take my breath from me,
Let not my worſer ſpirit tempt me againe,
To dye before you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Well pray you father.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Now good ﬁr what are you.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A moﬅ poore man, made lame by fortunes blowes,
Who by the Art of knowne and feeling ſorrowes
Am pregnant to good pitty. Giue me your hand,
Ile leade you to ſome biding.

speech.speaker: Gloﬅ.
speech.line: Hearty thankes, the bounty and the benizon of heauen to boot, to boot.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: A proclaim’d prize, moﬅ happy; that eyles head of thine was firﬅ framed fleſh to raiſe my fortunes. Thou moﬅ vnhappy Traitor, briefely thy ſelfe remember, the ſword is out that muﬅ deﬅroy thee.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Now let thy friendly hand put ﬅrength enough to’t.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Wherefore bolde pezant darﬅ thou ſupport a publiſht traytor, hence leaﬅ the infeƈtion of his fortune take like hold on thee, let go his arme.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chill not let go ﬁr without cagion.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Let go ﬂaue, or thou dieﬅ.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Good Gentleman goe your gate, let poore volke paﬀe: and chud haue beene zwaggar’d out of my life, it wold not haue bene zo long by a vortnight: nay come not neere the olde man, keepe out cheuore ye, or ile try whether your coﬅard or my bat be the harder, chill be plaine with you.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Out dunghill.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chil pick your teeth zir, come no matter for your foines.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Slaue thou haﬅ ﬂaine me, Villaine take my purſe:
If euer thou wilt thriue, bury my body,
And giue the Letters which thou findﬅ about me
To Edmund Earle of Gloﬅer, ſeeke him out, vpon
The Britiſh party: ô vntimely death! death.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I know thee well, a ſeruiceable villaine,
As dutious to the vices of thy Miﬅris,
As badneﬀ would deﬁre.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: What is he dead?

speech.speaker: Edg,
speech.line: Sit you downe father, reﬅ you, lets ſee his pockets,
Theſe Letters that he ſpeakes of may be my friends,
Hee’s dead, I am onely ſorry he had no other deathſman.
Let vs ſee, leaue gentle wax, and manners blame vs not,
To know our enemies minds wee’d rip their hearts,
Their papers is more lawfull.

emph.line: Let your reciprocall vowes be remembred,
You haue many opportunities to cut him off.
If your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered.
There is nothing done: If he returne the Conqueror,
Then am I the priſoner, and his bed my Iayle,
From the loath’d warmth whereof deliuer me,
And ſupply the place for your labour.

speech.line: Your wife (ſo I would ſay) & your affeƈtionate ſeruant, Gonorill.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O vndiﬅinguiſt ſpace of womans wit,
A plot vpon her vertuous husbands life,
And the exchange my Brother: heere in the ſands
Thee Ile rake vp, the poﬅ vnſanƈtified
Of murtherous letchers, and in the mature time
With this vngracious paper ﬅrike the ﬁght
Of the death praƈtiſd Duke, for him tis well,
That of his death and buﬁneﬀe I can tell.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: The King is mad, how ﬅiffe is my vilde ſenſe,
That I ﬅand vp, and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge ſorrowes, better I were diﬅraƈt,
So ſhould my thoughts be fenced from my greefes,
And woes by wrong imaginations, loſe
The knowledge of themſelnes.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand:
Farre off methinkes I heare the beaten drum.
Come Father Ile beﬅow you with a friend.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O thou good Kent,
How ſhall I liue and worke to match thy goodneﬀe,
My life will be too ſhort, and euery meaſure faile me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: To be acknowledg’d Madam is ore-paid,
All my reports go with the modeﬅ truth,
Nor more, nor clipt, but ſo.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Be better ſuited,
Theſe weeds are memories of thoſe worſer houres,
I prethee put them off.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Pardon me deere Madam,
Yet to be knowne ſhortens my made intent,
My boone I make it that you know me not,
Till time and I thinke meet.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Then be it ſo: my Lord how does the king.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Madam ﬂeepes ﬅill.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O you kinde Gods,
Cure this great breach in his abuſed nature,
The vntun’d and hurrying ſenſes, O winde vp,
Of this childe-changed Father.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Maieﬅy we may wake the King
He hath ﬂept long.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Be gouern’d by your knowledge, and proceede
Ith ſway of your owne will: is he array’d?

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: I Madam, in the heauineﬀe of his ﬂeepe,
We put freſh garments on him.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good madam be by when we do awake him,
I doubt not of his temperance.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Pleaſe you draw neere: louder the muﬁcke there.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O my deere father,
Reﬅoration hang thy medicine on my lippes,
And let this kiﬀe repaire thoſe violent harmes
That my two ﬁﬅers haue in thy reuerence made.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Kinde and deere Princeﬀe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Had you not bin their father, theſe white flakes
Had challeng’d pitty of them. Was this a face
To be expoſd againﬅ the warring windes,
To ﬅand againﬅ the deepe dread bolted thunder,
In the moﬅ terrible and nimble ﬅroke
Of quicke croﬀe lightning, to watch poor Per du,
With this thin helme? Mine iniurious dogge,
Though he had bit me, ſhould haue ﬅood that night
Againﬅ my fire, and waﬅ thou faine (poore father)
To houill thee with ſwine and rogues forlorne,
In ſhort and muﬅy ﬅraw? Alack, alacke,
Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once,
Had not concluded all. He wakes, ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Madam do you, tis fitteﬅ.

speech.speaker: C.
speech.line: How does my royal lord? how fares your maieﬅy

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You do me wrong to take me out a’th graue,
Thou art a ſoule in bliﬀe, but I am bound
Vpon a wheele of fire, that mine owne teares
Do ſcald like molten Lead.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Sir, know ye me?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Y’are a ſpirit I know, when did you dye?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Still, ﬅill, farre wide.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: He’s ſcarſe awake, let him alone awhile.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: Where haue I bin? where am I? faire day light!
I am mightily abuſd; I ſhould ene dye with pity
To ſee another thus. I know not what to ſay:
I will not ſweare theſe are my hands, let’s ſee,
I feele this pin pricke, would I were aﬀur’d of my condition.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O looke vpon me ﬁr,
And hold your hands in benediƈtion ore me,
No ﬁr you muﬅ not kneele.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Pray do not mocke me:
I am a very fooliſh fond olde man,
Foureſcore and vpward, and to deale plainly,
I feare I am not perfeƈt in my minde.
Me thinkes I ſhould know you, and know this man,
Yet I am doubtfull: for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is, and all the skill I haue
Remembers not theſe garments: nor I know not
Where I did lodge laﬅ night. Do no laugh at me,
For (as I am a man) I thinke this Lady
To be my childe Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: And ſo I am.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Be your teares wet? Yes faith: I pray weepe not,
If you haue poiſon for me I will drinke it:
I know you do not loue me, for your ﬁﬅers
Haue (as I do remember) done me wrong,
You haue ſome cauſe, they haue not.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: No cauſe, no cauſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Am I in France?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: In your owne kingdome ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do not abuſe me.

speech.speaker: Doƈt.
speech.line: Be comforted good Madame, the great rage you ſee is cured in him, and yet it is danger to make him euen ore the time hee has loﬅ: deﬁre him to goe in, trouble him no more till further ſetling.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your Highneﬀe walke?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You muﬅ beare with me:
Pray now forget and forgiue,
I am olde and fooliſh.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Holds it true ﬁr that the Duke of Cornwall was ſo ﬂaine?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Moﬅ certaine ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Who is conduƈtor of his people?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: As tis ſaid, the baﬅard ſonne of Gloﬅer.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: They ſay Edgar his baniſht ſonne, is with the Earle of
Kent in Germany.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Report is changeable, tis time to looke about,
The powers of the kingdome approach apace.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: The arbitrement is like to be bloody, fare you well ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My point and period will be throughly wrought,
Or well, or ill, as this dayes battels fought.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Edmund, Regan, and their powers.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Know of the Duke if his laﬅ purpoſe holde,
Or whether ﬁnce he is aduiſd by ought
To change the courſe, he is full of alteration
And ſelfe-reprouing, bring his conﬅant pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our ﬁﬅers man is certainly miſcarried.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Tis to be doubted Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Now ſweet Lord,
You know the goodneﬀe I intend vpon you:
Tell me truly, but then ſpeake the truth,
Do you not loue my ﬁﬅer?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I honor’d loue.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But haue you neuer found my brothers way,
To the forfended place?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: That thought abuſes you.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I am doubtfull that you haue beene coniunƈt
And boſom’d with her, as farre as we call hers.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: No by mine honor Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I neuer ſhall endure her,
Deere my Lord be not familiar with her.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Feare me not, ſhe and the Duke her husband.

speech.stagedir: Enter Albany and Gonorill with troopes.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: I had rather looſe the battell
Then that ﬁﬅer ſhould looſen him and me.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Our very louing ﬁﬅer well be-met,
For this I heare the King is come to his daughter
With others, whom the rigour of our State
Forc’d to cry out. Where I could not be honeﬅ
I neuer yet was valiant: for this buﬁneﬀe
It toucheth vs, as France inuades our land
Not bolds the king, with others whom I feare,
Moﬅ iuﬅ and heauy cauſes make oppoſe.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Sir you ſpeake nobly.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Why is this reaſon’d?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Combine together gainﬅ the enemy,
For theſe domeﬅicke doore particulars,
Are not the queﬅion heere.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Let vs then determine
With the Ancient of warre on our proceedings.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I ſhall attend you preſently at your Tent.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Siﬅer youle go with vs?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Tis moﬅ conuenient, pray you go with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: O ho, I know the Riddle, I will go.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: If ere your Grace had ſpeech with one ſo poore,
Heare me one word.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Ile ouertake you, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Before you fight the battell, ope this Letter,
If you haue viƈtory let the trumpet ſounde
For him that brought it, wretched though I ſeeme,
I can produce a Champion, that will prooue
What is auouched there. If you miſcarry,
Your buﬁneﬀe of the world hath ſo an end,
Fortune loue you.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay till I haue read the letter.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I was forbid it,
When time ſhall ſerue let but the Herald cry,
And Ile appeare againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Why fare thee well, I will looke ore the paper.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The enemy’s in view, draw vp your powers,
Hard is the gueﬀe of their great ﬅrength and forces
By diligēt diſcouery, but your haﬅ is now vrgd on you

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: We will greet the time.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: To both theſe ﬁﬅers haue I ſworne my loue,
Each iealous of the other, as the ﬅing are of the Adder,
Which of them ſhall I take, both one
Or neither; neither can be enioy’d
If both remaine aliue: to take the Widdow,
Exaſperates, makes mad her ﬁﬅer Gonorill,
And hardly ſhall I carry out my ﬁde
Her husband being aliue. Now then wee’l vſe
His countenance for the battell, which being done
Let her that would be rid of him deuiſe
His ſpeedy taking off: as for his mercie
Which he extends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The battell done, and they within our power,
Shall neuer ſee his pardon: for my ﬅate
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.

sceneref.stagedir: Alarum. Enter the powers of France ouer the ﬅage, Cordelia with her Father in her hand.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Heere Father, take the ſhadow of this buſh
For your good hoaﬅ: pray that the right may thriue.
If euer I returne to you againe,
Ile bring you comfort.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Grace go with you ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Away olde man, giue me thy hand, away,
King Lear hath loﬅ, he and his daughter tane:
Giue me thy hand, come on.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: No farther ﬁr, a man may rot euen heere.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What in ill thoughts agen? Men muﬅ endure,
Their going hence, euen as their comming hither,
Ripenesﬀe is all come on.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Edmund, with Lear and Cordelia priſoners.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Some officers take them away, good guard,
Vntill their greater pleaſures beﬅ be knowne
That are to cenſure them.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: We are not the firﬅ,
Who with beﬅ meaning haue incurr’d the worﬅ:
For thee oppreﬀed King am I caﬅ downe,
My ſelfe could elſe out-frowne falſe fortunes frowne.
Shall we not ſee theſe daughters, and theſe ﬁﬅers?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, no, come let’s away to priſon,
We two alone will ﬁng like birds i’th cage:
When thou doﬅ aske me bleﬃng, Ile kneele downe
And aske of thee forgiueneﬀe: ſo weell liue,
And pray, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded Butterflies, and heare poore Rogues
Talke of Court newes, and weel talke with them too,
Who looſes, and who wins; whoſe in, whoſe out;
And take vpon’s the myﬅery of things,
As if we were Gods ſpies: and weel weare out
In a walld priſon, packes and ſeƈts of great ones,
That ebbe and flow by the Moone.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Take them away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vpon ſuch ſacrifices my Cordelia
The gods themſelues throw incenſe. Haue I caught thee?
He that parts vs ſhall bring a brand from heauen,
And fire vs hence like Foxes, wipe thine eyes,
The good ſhall deuoure em, fleach and fell,
Ere they ſhall make vs weepe? Weele ſee em ﬅarue firﬅ.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Come hither Captaine, hearke.
Take thou this note, go follow them to priſon,
One ﬅep I haue aduaneﬅ thee, if thou doﬅ as this inﬅruƈts thee,
Thou doﬅ make thy way to Noble fortunes:
Know thou this, that men are as the time is;
To be tender minded does not become a ſword,
Thy great employment will not beare quesﬅion,
Either ſay thout do’t, or thriue by other meanes.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Ile doot my Lord.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: About it, and write happy when thou haﬅ done,
Marke I ſay inﬅantly, and carry it ſo
As I haue ſet it downe.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: I cannot draw a Cart, nor eate dryed oates,
If it be mans worke, Ile doo’t.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the Duke, the two Ladies, and others.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir you haue ſhewne to day your valiant ﬅraine,
And Fortune led you well: you haue the Captiues
That were the oppoﬁtes of this dayes ﬅrife:
We do require then of you ſo to vſe them,
As we ſhall finde their merits, and our ſafety
May equally determine.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Sir I thought it fit,
To ſend the olde and miſerable King
To ſome retention, and appointed guard,
Whoſe age has charmes in it, whoſe Title more,
To plucke the common bloﬀomes of his ﬁde,
And turne our impreﬅ Launces in our eyes
Which do command them. With him I ſent the Queene:
My reaſon all the ſame, and they are ready to morrow,
Or at a further ſpace, to appeare where you ſhall hold
Your Seﬃon at this time: we ſweate and bleed,
The friend hath loﬅ his friend, and the beﬅ quarrels
In the heate are curﬅ by thoſe that feele their ſharpeneﬀe.
The queﬅion of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place,

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir by your patience,
I hold you but a ſubieƈt of this warre, not as a brother.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: That’s as we liﬅ to grace him.
Methinkes our pleaſure ſhould haue beene demanded
Ere you had ſpoke ſo farre. He led our powers,
Bore the Commiﬃon of my place and perſon,
The which immediate may well ﬅand vp,
And call it ſelfe your brother.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not ſo hot: in his owne grace he doth exalt himſelfe,
More then in your aduancement.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: In my right by me inueﬅed, he compeers the beﬅ.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: That were the moﬅ, if he ſhould husband you.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ieﬅers do oft proue Prophets.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Hola, hola, that eye that told you ſo, lookt but a ſquint.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Lady I am not well, elſe I ſhould anſwer
From a full flowing ﬅomacke. Generall,
Take thou my ſoldiers, priſoners, patrimony,
Witneﬀe the world, that I create thee heere
My Lord and maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Meane you to enioy him then?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: The let alone lies not in your good will.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Nor in thine Lord.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Halfe blooded fellow, yes.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Let the drum ﬅrike, and proue my title good.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay yet, heare reaſon: Edmund I arreﬅ thee
On capitall treaſon; and in thine attaint,
This gilded Serpent: for your claime faire ﬁﬅer,
I bare it in the intereﬅ of my wife,
Tis ſhe is ſubcontraƈted to her Lord,
And I her husband contradiƈt the banes.
If you will marry, make your loue to me,
My Lady is beſpoke. Thou art arm’d Gloﬅer.
If none appeare to proue vpon thy head,
Thy hainous, manifeﬅ, and many treaſons,
There is my pledge, Ile proue it on thy heart
Ere I taﬅe bread, thou art in nothing leﬀe
Then I haue heere proclaim’d thee.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sicke, ô ﬁcke.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: If not, Ile nere truﬅ poyſon.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Ther’s my exchange, what in the world he is,
That names me traitor, villain-like he lyes,
Call by thy Trumpet, he that dares approach
On him, on you, who not, I will maintaine
My truth and honor firmely.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: A Herald ho.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: A herald ho, a herald.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Truﬅ to thy ﬁngle vertue, for thy ſoldiers
All leuied in my name, haue in my name tooke their diſcharge.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: This ﬁckneﬀe growes vpon me.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: She is not well, conuey her to my tent,
Come hither Herald, let the Trumpet ſound, and read out this.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Sound Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: If any man of quality or degree, in the hoaﬅ of the Army, will maintaine vpon Edmund ſuppoſed Earle of Gloceﬅer, that he’s a manifold traitor, let him appeare at the thirde ſound of the Trumpet: he is bold in his defence.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Sound. Againe.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Edgar at the third ſound, with a trumpet before him.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Aske him his purpoſes, why he appeares
Vpon this call o’th trumpet?

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: What are you? your name and quality?
And why you anſwer this preſent ſummons?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O know my name is loﬅ by Treaſons tooth:
Bare-gnawne and canker-bit,
Where is the aduerſary I come to cope with all?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What is that aduerſary?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What’s he that ſpeakes for Edmund Earle of Gloﬅer?

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Himſelfe, what ſayﬅ thou to him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Draw thy ſword.
That if my ſpeech offend a noble heart, thy arme
May do thee iuﬅice, heere is mine:
Behold it is the priuiledge of my tongue,
My oath and profeﬃon, I proteﬅ,
Maugre thy ﬅrength, youth, place and eminence,
Deſpight thy viƈtor, ſword, and fire new fortun’d,
Thy valor, and thy heart, thou art a traitor:
Falſe to the gods, thy brother, and thy father,
Conſpicuate gainﬅ this high illuﬅrious Prince,
And from th’extremeﬅ vpward of thy head,
To the deſcent and duﬅ beneath thy feet,
A moﬅ toad-ſpotted traitor: ſay thou no,
This ſword, this arme, and my beﬅ ſpirits,
Is bent to proue vpon thy heart, whereto I ſpeake thou lyeﬅ.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: In wiſedome I ſhould aske thy name,
But ﬁnce thy outﬁde lookes ſo faire and warlike,
And that thy being ſome ſay of breeding breathes,
By right of knight-hood I diſdaine and ſpurne,
With the hell hatedly ore-turn’d thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by, and ſcarſely bruiſe,
This ſword of mine ſhall giue them inﬅant way,
Where they ſhall reﬅ for euer, Trumpets ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Saue him, ſaue him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: This is meere praƈtiſe Gloﬅer, by the law of Armes
Thou art not bound to offer an vnknowne oppoﬁte,
Thou art not vanquiſht, but couſned and beguild.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stop your mouth Dame, or with this paper ſhall I ﬅop it: thou worſe then any thing, reade thine owne euill. Nay, no tearing Lady, I perceiue you know’t.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Say if I do, the lawes are mine not thine, who ſhal araign me for it.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Monﬅer, knowﬅ thou this paper?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Aske me not what I know.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Go after her, ſhe’s deſperate, gouerne her.

speech.speaker: Baﬆ.
speech.line: What you haue charg’d me with, that haue I done,
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
Tis paﬅ, and ſo am I: but what art thou that haﬅ this fortune on me? If thou beeﬅ noble, I do forgiue thee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Let’s exchange charity,
I am no leﬀe in blood then thou art Edmund,
If more, the more thou haﬅ wrongd me.
My name is Edgar, and thy fathers ſonne,
The Gods are iuﬅ, and of our pleaſant vertues
Make inﬅruments to ſcourge vs: the darke and vitious place
Where he thee got, coﬅ him his eyes.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Thou haﬅ ſpoken truth,
The wheele is come full circkled I am heere.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Me thought thy very gate did propheﬁe
A royall nobleneﬀe, I muﬅ embrace thee,
Let ſorow ſplit my heart if I did euer hate thee or thy father.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Worthy Prince I know it.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where haue you hid your ſelfe?
How haue you knowne the miſeries of your father?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: By nurﬁng them my Lord,
Liﬅ a breefe tale, and when tis told,
O that my heart would burﬅ. The bloody proclamation
To eſcape that followed me ſo neere,
(O our liues ſweetneﬀe, that with the paine of death
VVould hourely dye, rather then dye at once)
Taught me to ſhift into a mad-mans rags,
To aﬀume a ſemblance that very dogges diſdain’d:
And in this habit met I my father with his bleeding rings,
The precious ﬅones new loﬅ; Became his guide,
Led him, begd for him, ſau’d him from diſpaire.
Neuer (O Father) reueald my ſelfe vnto him,
Vntill ſome halfe houre paﬅ when I was arm’d,
Not ſure, though hoping of this good ſucceﬀe,
I askt his bleﬃng, and from firﬅ to laﬅ
Told him my pilgrimage: but his flawd heart
Alacke too weake the confliƈt to ſupport,
Twixt two extremes of paﬃon, ioy and greefe,
Burﬅ ſmilingly.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: This ſpeech of yours hath mooued me,
And ſhall perchance do good, but ſpeake you on,
You looke as you had ſomething more to ſay.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: If there be any more more wofull, hold it in.
For I am almoﬅ readie to diﬀolue.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This would haue ſeem’d a period to ſuch
As loue not ſorrow, but another to amplifie too much,
VVould make much more, and top extremity.
VVhilﬅ I was big in clamor, came there in a man,
VVho hauing ſeene me in my worﬅ eﬅate,
Shund my abhord ſociety: but then finding
Who twas that ſo indur’d, with his ﬅrong armes
He faﬅened on my necke, and bellowd out
As hee’d burﬅ heauen, threw me on my father,
And told the pitteous tale of Lear and him,
That euer eare receiued, which in recounting
His greefe grew puiſant, and the ﬅrings of life
Began to cracke twice, then the trumpets ſounded,
And there I left him traunﬅ.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: But who was this?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Kent ﬁr, the baniſt Kent, who in diſguiſe,
Followed his enemy king, and did him ſeruice
Improper for a ﬂaue.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter one with a bloody knife.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Helpe, helpe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What kinde of helpe? what meanes that bloody knife?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Its hot, it ſmokes, it came euen from the heart of―

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Who man? ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Your Lady ﬁr, your Lady; and her ﬁﬅer
By her is poyſon’d: ſhe has confeﬅ it.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I was contraƈted to them both, all three
Now marry in an inﬅant.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Produce their bodies be they aliue or dead:
This iuﬅice of the heauens that makes vs tremble,
Touches vs not with pity.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Here comes Kent ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: O tis he, the time will not allow
The complement that very manners vrges.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I am come to bid my King and maﬅer aye good night,
Is he not heere?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Great things of vs forgot. Speake Edmund, where’s the king, and wher’s Cordelia? Seeﬅ thou this obieƈt Kent?

sceneref.stagedir: The bodies of Gonorill & Regan are brought in.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alacke, why thus.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Yet Edmund was belou’d: the one the other poiſond for my ſake, and after ﬂew her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Euen ſo, couer their faces.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: I pant for life: ſome good I meane to do deſpight of my owne nature. Quickly ſend, bee briefe, into the Caﬅle for my Writ, tis on the life of Lear, & on Cordelia: nay, ſend in time.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Run, run, O run.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: To who my Lord? who hath the office?
Send thy token of repreeue.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: Well thought on, take my ſword, giue it the Captaine.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Haﬅ thee for thy life.

speech.speaker: Baﬅ.
speech.line: He hath commiﬃon from thy wife & me, to hang Cordelia in the priſon, and to lay the blame vpon her own deſpaire.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: The Gods defend her, beare him hence a while.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Howle, howle, howle, howle: O you are men of ﬅones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, I would vſe them ſo,
That heauens vault ſhould cracke: O, ſhe is gone for euer.
I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
Shees dead as earth: Lend me a looking-glaﬀe,
If that her breath will miﬅ and ﬅaine the ﬅone, ſhe then liues.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is this the promiﬅ end?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Or image of that horror?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Fall and ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This feather ﬅirs, ſhe liues, if it be ſo, it is a chance that do’s redeeme all ſorrowes that euer I haue felt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A my good maﬅer.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prethee away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tis Noble Kent your friend.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A plague vpon you murdrous traitors all, I might haue ſaued her, now ſhees gone for euer: Cordelia, Cordelia, ﬅay a little. What iﬅ thou ſayﬅ? her voice was euer ſoft, gentle & low, an excellent thing in women. I kild the ﬂaue that was a hanging thee.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Tis true my Lords hee did.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Did I not fellow? I ha ſeene the day, that with my biting Fauchion I would haue made them skip: I am old now, and theſe ſame croﬀes ſpoile me. Who are you? Mine eyes are none o’th beﬅ, Ile tell you ﬅraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If Fortune bragd of two ſhe loued or hated,
One of them we behold.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Are not you Kent?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: The ſame your ſeruant Kent, wher is your ſeruāt Caius?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Hees a good fellow, I can tell that,
Heel ﬅrike and quickly too, hees dead and rotten.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No my good Lord, I am the very man.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile ſee that ﬅraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: That from your life of difference and decay,
Haue followed your ſad ﬅeps.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You are welcome hether.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor no man elſe: All’s cheereleﬀe, darke, and deadly,
Your eldeﬅ daughters haue fore-doom’d themſelues,
And deſperately are dead.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So I thinke too.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: He knowes not what he ſees, and vaine it is,
That we preſent vs to him.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: Very bootleﬀe.

speech.speaker: Cap:
speech.line: Edmund is dead my Lord.

speech.speaker: Alb:
speech.line: Thats but a trifle heere: you Lords and Noble friends, know our intent, what comfort to this decay may come, ſhalbe applied: for vs we will reﬁgne during the life of this old maieﬅy to him our abſolute power, you to your rights with boote, and ſuch addition as your honors haue more then merited, al friends ſhall taﬅe the wages of their vertue, and all foes the cup of their deſeruings: O ſee, ſee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And my poore foole is hangd: no, no life, why ſhould a dog, a horſe, a rat haue life and thou no breath at all? O thou wilt come no more, neuer, neuer, neuer: pray vndo this button; thanke you ﬁr, O, o, o, o, o.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: He faints, my Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear:
speech.line: Breake heart, I prethe breake.

speech.speaker: Edg:
speech.line: Looke vp my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent:
speech.line: Vex not his ghoﬅ, O let him paﬀe,
he hates him much, that would vpon the wracke
Of this tough world ﬅretch him out longer.

speech.speaker: Edg:
speech.line: O he is gone indeed.

speech.speaker: Kent:
speech.line: The wonder is, he hath endured ſo long,
He but vſurpt his life.

speech.speaker: Duke:
speech.line: Beare them from hence, our preſent buﬁneﬀe
Is to generall woe: friends of my ſoule, you twaine
Rule in this kingdome, and the good ﬅate ſuﬅaine.

speech.speaker: Kent:
speech.line: I haue a iourney ﬁr, ſhortly to go,
My maﬅer cals, and I muﬅ not ſay no.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: The waight of this ſad time we muﬅ obay,
Speake what we feele, not what we ought to ſay:
The oldeﬅ haue borne moﬅ, we that are yong,
Shall neuer ſee ſo much, nor liue ſo long.
